We applied the proposed method to analyze 391 personal PM2.5 samples collected in an epidemiological study conducted in urban Beijing. By comparing the results with the ambient concentrations from a fixed monitoring site, we found that the con-centrations of some metallic components in personal PM2.5 samples were significantly different from those in the corresponding fixed-site samples, with up to an order of magnitude difference. Because personal sampling can reduce the potential for exposure misclassifications, the high-resolution temporal analysis of metallic compo-nents in personal samples using the mu-SRXRF method could be a useful approach for exploring the health risks and identifying the sources of metallic components of PM2.5.
keywords: Aerosols
title2: quantifying metallic components in aerosol filter samples using microsynchrotron radiation xray fluorescence with quartz filter as an example

title: Integrated bioinformatics and network pharmacology to explore the therapeutic target and molecular mechanisms of Bailing capsule on polycystic ovary syndrome
authors: Guan, Hao-ru and Li, Bo and Zhang, Ze-hua and Wu, Han-song and He, Xing-lishang and Dong, Ying-jie and Su, Jie and Lv, Gui-yuan and Chen, Su-hong
abstract: BackgroundPolycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a complex endocrine and metabolic disorder that is common in women of reproductive age. The clinical features of PCOS include hyperandrogenemia and polycystic ovarian changes. Bailing capsule (BL), a proprietary Chinese medicine that contains fermented Cordyceps sinensis powder, has been applied to treat PCOS. However, the specific active ingredients of BL and its mechanisms of action are yet to be elucidated.MethodsInitially, the effectiveness of BL on PCOS model mice was evaluated. Subsequently, the active ingredients of BL were searched in the TCMSP and TCM Systems Pharmacology databases, and their targets were predicted using Swiss Target Prediction and SEA databases. Furthermore, the GEO gene database was used to screen for differentially expressed genes (DEGs) related to PCOS. Data from Gene Card, OMIM, DDT, and Drugbank databases were then combined to establish a PCOS disease gene library. Cross targets were imported into the STRING database to construct a protein-protein interaction network. In addition, GO and KEGG pathway enrichment analyses were performed using Metascape and DAVID databases and visualized using Cytoscape software and R 4.2.3. The core targets were docked with SYBYL-X software, and their expressions in PCOS mice were further verified using qPCR.ResultsThe core active ingredients of BL were identified to be linoleyl acetate, cholesteryl palmitate, arachidonic acid, among others. Microarray data sets from four groups containing disease and normal samples were obtained from the GEO database. A total of 491 DEGs and 106 drug-disease cross genes were selected. Estrous cycle and ovarian lesions were found to be improved in PCOS model mice following BL treatment. While the levels of testosterone, progesterone, and prolactin decreased, that of estradiol increased. qPCR findings indicated that the expressions of JAK2, PPARG, PI3K, and AKT1 were upregulated, whereas those of ESR1 and IRS1 were downregulated in PCOS model mice. After the administration of BL, the expressions of associated genes were regulated. This study demonstrated that BL exerted anti-PCOS effects via PIK3CA, ESR1, AKT, PPARG, and IRS1 targets affecting PI3K-Akt signaling pathways.DiscussionThis research clarified the multicomponent, multitarget, and multichannel action of BL and provided a theoretical reference for further investigations on its pharmacological basis and molecular mechanisms against PCOS.
keywords: Computational Biology;Ovary;Capsules;Polycystic Ovary Syndrome
title2: integrated bioinformatics and network pharmacology to explore the therapeutic target and molecular mechanisms of bailing capsule on polycystic ovary syndrome

title: Comparative metagenomic analysis of human intervertebral disc nucleus pulposus and cartilaginous end plates
authors: Shanmuganathan, Rajasekaran and Tangavel, Chitraa and An and , Sri Vijay K. S. and Muthurajan, Raveendran and Nayagam, Sharon Miracle and Matchado, Monica Steffi and Rajendran, Sunmathi and Kanna, Rishi Mugesh and Shetty, Ajoy Prasad
abstract: Study designThe diversity of microflora inhabiting endplate (EP) and nucleus pulposus (NP) tissues of human intervertebral disc (IVD) was profiled through NGS-supported 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing. Sixteen EP and their corresponding NP were excised from the brain-dead voluntary organ donors with no clinical history of low back pain, and 12 herniated and 8 degenerated NP tissues isolated from the patients undergoing spinal surgery were subjected to study the alteration in the microbial diversity. Objective(s)To understand in normal IVD, whether the colonization of bacteria to the NP is through the EP in discs with intact annulus fibrosus. To identify significantly differing microbial population(s) between normal and diseased IVD (NP). Background of the studyThere is increasing evidence for subclinical infection by fastidious low, growing bacteria to be a cause of disc degeneration. Although the presence of bacteria in NP has been reported well in literature, the source of bacteria is not clearly proved as the disc is avascular in healthy condition. Documentation of similar bacterial populations in the EP and NP may add proof that bacterial inoculation of NP occurs via the EP. Materials and methodsSixteen EP and their corresponding NP excised from brain-dead voluntary organ donors with no history of back pain and 20 diseased discs collected from patients undergoing microdiscectomy/fusion surgery were used for profiling microbiome through 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing using primers specific for V1-V9 hypervariable regions. Changes in bacterial diversity and abundance were analysed to identify the key microbial populations in normal IVD NP and EP tissues and those significantly altered in diseased IVD (NP). ResultsNP and EP shared a similar spectrum of microbiome but with varying abundance. The five dominant phyla identified were Proteobacteria, Firmicutes, Actinobacteria, OD1, and Bacteroidetes. Proteobacteria was found to be the most abundant phyla in both NP (62\%) and EP (53\%) of the normal IVD. This was followed by Firmicutes (16\%), Actinobacteriota (11\%), OD1 (Parcubacteria) (7.6\%), and Bacteroidetes (2\%) in NP and Firmicutes (23.4\%), OD1 (Parcubacteria) (17.6\%), Actinobacteriota (2.8\%), and Bacteroidetes (2.6\%) in EP, respectively. Under diseased conditions, Proteobacteria (68\%) was dominant when compared with other phyla. However, there was no significant difference in the abundance of Proteobacteria between the normal and diseased discs. Interestingly, the other dominant phyla such as Firmicutes (Normal-NP: 16.2\%; Diseased-NP: 4.02\%) and Actinobacteria (Normal-NP: 11\%; Diseased-NP: 0.99\%) showed a significant reduction in degenerated discs. To understand the key microbial populations that are significantly altered during disease, correlation analysis was performed among the three phyla, which revealed a negative correlation in the ratio of Actinobacteria + Firmicutes vs. Proteobacteria (p = 0.001) in DD. ConclusionResults of our study clearly demonstrated a similar bacterial diversity but with varying abundance between the EP and NP, suggesting the existence of the endplate-nucleus pulposus axis in the normal IVD microbiome. Further, our results have indicated that the changes in the abundance of Actinobacteria + Firmicutes vs. Proteobacteria during DDD need further investigation.
keywords: Humanities;Humanism;Humans;Intervertebral Disc
title2: comparative metagenomic analysis of human intervertebral disc nucleus pulposus and cartilaginous end plates

title: Perfluoroalkyl acid precursors in agricultural soil-plant systems: Occurrence, uptake, and biotransformation
authors: Ye, Beibei and Wang, Jiaxi and Zhou, Lei and Yu, Xia and Sui, Qian
abstract: Perfluoroalkyl acid (PFAA) precursors have been used in various consumer and industrial products due to their hydrophobic and oleophobic properties. In recent years, PFAA precursors in agricultural soil-plant systems have received increasing attention as they are susceptible to biotransformation into metabolites with high biotoxicity risks to human health. In this review, we systematically assessed the occurrence of PFAA precursors in agricultural soils, taking into account their sources and biodegradation pathways. In addition, we summarized the findings of the relevant literature on the uptake and biotransformation of PFAA precursors by agricultural plants. The applications of biosolids/composts and pesticides are the main sources of PFAA precursors in agricultural soils. The physicochemical properties of PFAA precursors, soil organic carbon (SOC) contents, and plant species are the key factors influencing plant root uptakes of PFAA precursors from soils. This review revealed, through toxicity assessment, the potential of PFAA precursors to generate metabolites with higher toxicity than the parent precursors. The results of this paper provide a reference for future research on PFAA precursors and their metabolites in soil-plant systems.
keywords: Biotransformation
title2: perfluoroalkyl acid precursors in agricultural soilplant systems occurrence uptake and biotransformation

title: Polychlorinated biphenyls and risk of metabolic syndrome and comparison with the risk of diabetes: A systematic review and meta-analysis
authors: Gao, Xin and Yan, Di and Li, Guangying and Wei, Yu and He, Huan and Zhai, Jinxia
abstract: With the increasing incidence of metabolic syndrome (MetS) worldwide and no consistent results on PCBs and MetS. A meta-analysis to explore their relationship was conducted. Given the high correlation and overlap of MetS with diabetes, analysis of diabetes risk, was used as a supplement to compare with MetS. Seven studies included MetS, 15 studies for diabetes, and one study included both outcomes. It was found that PCBs may not be a risk factor for MetS, but their high heterogeneity indicates that they are under-represented. In addition, our results showed that total PCBs might be a protective factor against diabetes. In the whole blood subgroup, which can reflect the accumulation of more than one body load, heterogeneity was reduced, and its OR value suggested that PCBs increased the risk of MetS in the whole blood biomaterial. DL-PCBs were positively associated with MetS and diabetes, while NDL-PCBs were negatively associated with diabetes. In the subgroup analysis of PCBs homologs, DL-PCB-126 and DL-PCB-118 were risk factors for MetS and diabetes, respectively. In addition, PCB153 and 180 showed a dose-response relationship between them and diabetes mellitus, respectively. The results of total analysis of MetS and diabetes mellitus and subgroup analysis of PCBs were mixed, and this reason might be attributed to the different mechanisms of action and effect sizes of different PCBs, so based on subgroup results and in vivo and in vitro experiments, we considered PCBs to be a risk factor for MetS and diabetes. Due to various reasons, there are still many shortcomings in the evaluation of PCBs impact on human health, and more high-quality research are needed to further explore the role of PCBs of different species and congeners in MetS and diabetes.
title2: polychlorinated biphenyls and risk of metabolic syndrome and comparison with the risk of diabetes a systematic review and metaanalysis

title: The role of environmental pollutants in body composition: Systematic review and meta-analysis
authors: Duque-Cartagena, Tatiana and Mundstock, Eduardo and Dalla Bernardina, Marcello Dala and Padoin, Alex and re Vontobel and Canon-Montanez, Wilson and Mattiello, Rita
abstract: The effects of environmental pollution are associated with higher rates of mortality, morbidity, and years of life lost. It is known that these produce alterations in the human body, including changes in body composition. Research has focused on the association between contaminants and BMI through cross-sectional studies. The objective of this study was to synthesize the evidence for the association of pollutants on different measures of body composition. The PECOS strategy was defined, in which ``P{''}: participants of any age, sex, or ethnicity, ``E{''}: a higher level of environmental pollution, ``C{''}: a lower level of environmental pollution, ``O{''}: body composition measurements and ``S{''}: longitudinal studies. Studies from the following databases were included: MEDLINE, EMBASE, SciELO, LILACS, Scopus, Web of Science, SPORTDiscus, and gray literature from inception to January 2023.3069 studies were identified, 18 were included in the systematic review, and 13 in the meta-analysis. These studies included 8.563 people, 47 environmental contaminants, and 16 measures of body composition. The meta -analysis by subgroup found that the association between dioxins, furans, PCBs, and waist circumference was beta = 1.0 (95\% CI: 0.85 to 1.16; I2: 95\%), and the sum of four skinfolds beta = 1.02 (95\% CI: 0.88 to 1.16; I2: 24\%). The association between pesticides and waist circumference was beta = 1.00 (95\% CI: 0.68 to 1.32; I2: 98\%), and the fat mass was beta = 0.99 (95\% CI: 0.17 to 1.81; I2: 94\%). Pollutants, especially endocrine-disrupting chemicals, among which dioxins, furans, PCBs, and pesticides, are associated with changes in body composition, mainly with waist circumference and the sum of four skinfolds.
keywords: Body Composition
title2: the role of environmental pollutants in body composition systematic review and metaanalysis

title: Suicide and suicidality in people exposed to pesticides: A systematic review and meta-analysis{*}
authors: Wu, Hong and Li, Kaidi and Wang, Yiyu and Huang, Ronggui and Jin, Xue and Li, Xianbao and Wang, Hua and Li, Baozhu
abstract: Exposure to pesticides has been proposed to be a positive association in suicide and suicidality. Many studies have explored this topic, but have reported inconsistent findings. We carried out a systematic review and metaanalysis of the now existing evidence on the association between pesticide exposure and the risk of suicide and suicidality. We searched PubMed, EMBASE and Web of Science databases for studies published up to February 1, 2023. For studies that provided detailed data, we applied quantitative meta-analysis to calculate Odds ratio (OR) with 95\% Confidence Intervals (CIs) to evaluate the results. Heterogeneity among the included studies was assessed using Cochran's Q test, I2 statistic and tau-squared (tau 2). Publication bias was evaluated by funnel plots, Egger's test, and Begg's test. In addition, subgroup analyses according to pesticides category and geographical area were performed. 2906 studies were initially identified, and 20 studies were eventually included. Fifteen of the studies were on suicide deaths and suicide attempts, and five were on suicidal ideation. Pesticide exposure was positively related to suicide deaths and suicide attempts (pooled OR = 1.31; 95\%CI: 1.04-1.64, p < 0.001) and suicidal ideation (pooled OR = 2.43; 95\%CI: 1.51-3.91, p = 0.015). In the subgroup analysis, mixed pesticide type (pooled OR = 1.55; 95\%CI: 1.39-1.74) increased the risk of suicide deaths and suicide attempts. The results of the analysis by geographic area showed that the risk of suicide deaths and suicide attempts with pesticide exposure was 2.27 (95\%CI = 1.36-3.78), and 1.33 (95\%CI = 1.14-1.56) in Asia and Europe, respectively. The risk of suicidal ideation caused by pesticide exposure in Asia and America were 2.19 (95\%CI = 1.08-4.42) and 2.99 (95\%CI = 1.76-5.06). In conclusion, pesticide exposure may increase the risk of suicide and suicidality based on the current evidence.
keywords: Suicide;Pesticides
title2: suicide and suicidality in people exposed to pesticides a systematic review and metaanalysis

title: Environmental and occupational factors and higher risk of couple infertility: a systematic review study
authors: Abdoli, Sara and Masoumi, Seyedeh Zahra and Kazemi, Farideh
abstract: Background: Infertility is a global health problem that represents an increasing trend due to new lifestyles following technological advances since individuals are facing more risk factors than before. The present systematic review study aimed to investigate the impact of environmental and occupational factors on reproductive parameters and increased risk of couple infertility. Main body: Scopus, PubMed, SID, and Web of Science databases were searched for the available observational (i.e., cohort, case-control, and cross-sectional) systematic review, meta-analysis, and clinical trial studies between 2007 and 2019. To this end, keywords such as `Environmental exposure', `Occupational exposure', `Environmental pollutants', `Environmental pollution', `Couple infertility', `Sterility', and `Sub-fertility' were used. The retrieved investigations examined the impact of environmental and occupational risk factors on reproductive indices and increased infertility risk. Totally, 66 out of 9519 papers were evaluated after considering the inclusion and exclusion criteria. The reported risk factors in the reviewed studies were heavy metals, cigarette smoking, and exposure to chemicals through consumer goods, urban life, and proximity to main roads. In addition, occupational factors included heavy physical activity, prolonged sitting, exposure to a hot environment, contact with formaldehyde, pesticides, insecticides, mechanical vibration, and contact with ionizing radiation, all of which affected the reproductive parameters. However, some researchers found no significant associations in this regard. Short conclusion: In general, individuals with known impairments in reproductive parameters were more exposed to risk factors. Nonetheless, more studies are needed to determine the risk of infertility in the population.
title2: environmental and occupational factors and higher risk of couple infertility a systematic review study

title: Current opinion: postpartum urinary disorders
authors: Dong, Shirley M. and Hickman, Lisa C.
abstract: Purpose of reviewThe aim of this study was to describe the common postpartum urinary sequelae including urinary retention and incontinence, and to summarize the management of these conditions.Despite the high frequency of urinary disorders in obstetrics, screening and management protocols are rarely utilized by providers. Large variation exists in the literature regarding assessment of postpartum urinary retention, values of postvoid residuals and management of indwelling catheters in the immediate postpartum population. Recent expert guidance outlines a strategy for managing this condition.Research also highlights that screening for peripartum urinary incontinence is not a routine practice. The diagnosis is made more challenging by the fact that patients commonly understate and over-normalize their symptoms. Emerging studies have found that pelvic floor muscle training is cost-effective, preventive, and may improve symptoms in the postpartum setting.Increased awareness of urinary disorders in pregnancy and postpartum is imperative for appropriate diagnosis and management. Instituting standardized voiding protocols postpartum will allow providers to avoid undiagnosed postpartum urinary retention and its repercussions. Improved screening and education regarding urinary incontinence in the peripartum is important for early management, such as pelvic floor muscle training, and improved quality of life.Papers of particular interest, published within the annual period of review, have been highlighted as:While society places a large emphasis on antepartum obstetrical care, there continues to be insufficient patient education and awareness about the fourth trimester, or the first 12 weeks after giving birth, including the many short and long-term sequalae associated with delivery. Notably, education about peripartum pelvic floor disorders (PFDs) is often ignored during pregnancy, with studies finding that patients between the ages of 19 and 39 years were the least proficient regarding the topic {[}1]. PFDs are associated with decreased quality of life, psychological strain and a sense of patient embarrassment {[}2]. Out of the three domains of PFDs, urinary symptom distress is the most common in obstetrics, with 41.8\% of patients reporting these issues {[}2]. These symptoms may present at opposite ends of the spectrum during the postpartum period with urinary retention and urinary incontinence. As such, the purpose of this article is to educate providers on how to prevent, recognize and manage postpartum urinary sequelae. no caption availableGenitourinary system changes associated with pregnancy begin in the first trimester. The underlying mechanisms contributing to these dynamic changes are multifaceted. Elevation in the level of progesterone may lead to decreased urethral pressures, relaxation of urinary system smooth muscle and impaired detrusor contractility {[}3]. Renal changes include an increase in glomerular filtration rates and dilation of the ureters, resulting in increased urine production and functional bladder volumes. The enlarging gravid uterus contributes to bladder compression and can lead to urinary frequency, urgency and incontinence {[}2,4]. Together, these genitourinary system changes make bladder control issues a common phenomenon antepartum, and for some, persistent postpartum.Aspects of the birthing process are thought to predispose some individuals to the development of urinary disorders as well. Mechanical forces from pushing cause anatomical changes with inevitable bladder descent and compression. This may result in cellular injury, causing neurogenic dysfunction and consequently diminished sensation associated with bladder filling {[}5]. Lack of bladder sensation may lead to a vicious cycle where further overdistention of the bladder may in turn result in continued damage and reduced detrusor contractility.Epidurals and other forms of neuraxial anesthesia may also predispose individuals to postpartum voiding dysfunction due to disruption of afferent bladder innervations {[}6]. This disruption consequently interferes with the ability of the pontine micturition center to signal for detrusor muscle contraction and urethral sphincter relaxation {[}7].Traumatic birth processes such as perineal edema, advanced lacerations and hematomas may cause mechanical bladder outlet obstruction {[}6]. Other sources of birth trauma may involve levator ani muscle avulsion and nerve injury involving the pelvic, hypogastric and pudendal nerves which can affect sensation and continence {[}3,8]. Obstetric anal sphincter injuries and other lacerations may also impair reflexive and voluntary relaxation of the urethrae sphincter and periurethral muscles {[}3]. While these outcomes may be identified during a patient's postpartum care, their physiologic consequences also predispose patients to postpartum urinary retention (PUR) and urinary dysfunction, a diagnosis that may be more nuanced to identify.PUR is a relatively common postpartum phenomenon with a wide range of incidence in the literature, ranging from 1.5 to 45\% {[}9]. This large variance is likely due to a variety of reasons, including most importantly the lack of standardized definitions and management protocols for PUR. Consequently, only approximately 30\% of United States labor and delivery institutions have an established protocol for PUR evaluation and management, which thereby contributes to a wide variation in PUR recognition clinically {[}3].There are three main subtypes of PUR, outlined in Table 1. Individuals with PUR may present with symptoms similar to nonobstetric postoperative patients, including low urine output, frequency, dysuria, suprapubic fullness or hesitancy to void {[}3]. In an obstetric-specific clinical scenario, additional findings may include displaced fundal exams (both in height and in lateral displacement) and increased vaginal bleeding due to impaired ability for the uterus to contract down {[}3]. As implied by the definition of covert PUR, individuals may also be asymptomatic. A multitude of risk factors described in Table 2 may predispose certain individuals to PUR. As such, PUR may go undiagnosed if proper screening protocols are not in place.Subtypes of postpartum urinary retentionPUR, postpartum urinary retention.Risk factors for postpartum urinary retention {[}5,6,9,10]ISC, intermittent straight catheterization; OASIS, obstetric anal sphincter injuries.Importantly, mismanaged PUR may lead to rare long-term repercussions, including noncontractile fibrosis of the detrusor muscle and bladder rupture {[}3]. Previous research has shown that PUR may take up to 42 days to resolve, with some studies also reporting prolonged voiding dysfunction at intervals 1-3 years after delivery {[}8]. These findings stress the importance of both creating and utilizing a set of standardized recommendations to manage PUR.Early diagnosis is essential in PUR management. The amount of variation in the literature regarding PUR likely leads to decreased awareness and impaired diagnosis. While the previously described definitions in Table 1 are the most common established in the literature, it is notable that there is variance in the specific postvoid residual (PVR) cut-offs {[}5,10]. The most common PVR cut-off remains 150 ml, without consequent adverse outcomes with using this volume {[}11]. Given that values above 200 ml may reflect inadequate bladder emptying and values less than 100 ml may be a normal variant, 150 ml should remain the standard abnormal PVR cut-off.The route of measurement of PVRs varies greatly in the literature. A systemic review of PUR found the majority of studies used transabdominal ultrasounds or ultrasonic measurement devices (commonly known as a bladder scanner) to measure PVR rather than intermittent self-catheterization (ISC) {[}12]. While bladder scanners may be convenient and easy to use, there is evidence these devices in the postpartum period may have low accuracy with +/- 15\% error, leading to discrepancies averaging 42.7 ml between measuring modalities {[}12,13]. Alternatively, transabdominal ultrasound is costly, time-consuming and requires a qualified ultrasonographer {[}14]. Creation of a stepwise standardized protocol including first using bladder scanners and then performing ISC if an elevated PVR is identified may therefore prevent unnecessary invasive testing.There is also significant variation of indwelling catheter usage following delivery. A review found in patients who underwent cesarean section, removal of urinary catheters greater than 24 h postoperatively decreased the risk of urinary retention, while removal less than 6 h postoperatively was associated with decreased risk of UTI and decreased the length to first ambulation {[}15]. Conversely, a randomized controlled trial found patients diagnosed with PUR had significant shorter timeframes to PUR resolution when managed with ISC, with no difference in UTI rates or length of hospital stay between the two management modalities {[}16]. A study comparing bedpan use versus mobilizing to the toilet postpartum found significantly higher micturition rates in individuals who used the toilet versus the bedpan {[}17]. This highlights simple behavioral modifications during recovery can be protective against PUR. Integration of these findings to a patient's postpartum care, with the addition of patient education on good bladder hygiene, are simple interventions that may help prevent bladder dysfunction.Utilization of a standardized protocol such as that presented in Nutaitis et al.{[}3] (Fig. 1) would therefore integrate evidence-based recommendations into a regimented postpartum bladder protocol. The protocol recommends measuring the first two spontaneous voids after delivery and/or catheter removal to ensure appropriate bladder emptying. Additionally, the protocol highlights when and how PVRs should be performed and methods of bladder rest if PUR is diagnosed. Further testing, including active void trials, is also recommended to ensure a patient's PUR has resolved. This testing can be broadly utilized in both the inpatient and outpatient setting if a patient's symptoms do not resolve while admitted. Lastly, methods of outpatient management are suggested to include both ISC and indwelling catheter after educated patient shared decision making. As the majority of PUR cases resolve within 72 h, the protocol is best integrated into postpartum care units and its algorithmic nature makes it easy to follow.Postpartum bladder management protocol.Given only 17. 1\% of surveyed Obstetrics and Gynecology residents reported receiving formal PUR training, the largest area for improvement is provider education {[}18]. Formal education increased the likelihood that trainees were able to identify concerning clinical scenarios suggestive of PUR. An additional auditing study found nurses overall had minimal training on identification and management of PUR {[}19]. This study audited criteria such as encouraging regular voids intrapartum, recording strict fluid input and output both in the intrapartum and postpartum period, and ensuring individuals had two adequate spontaneous voids after delivery. After educational strategies were implemented, the study found reductions in both PUR incidence and the time to void after delivery {[}19]. Taken together, healthcare provider education on PUR is effective for properly identifying and managing abnormal voiding patterns and is important for improving patient outcomes.Active patient management remains the most important strategy for PUR management. However, bethanechol is FDA approved for the PUR treatment {[}20]. Bethanechol acts by activating bladder muscarinic receptors, which increases detrusor muscle tone to aid in bladder emptying {[}20]. However, this agent has notable cardiac, pulmonary and gastrointestinal adverse effects which limit broad application. Additionally, there is no established literature regarding the usage of bethanechol while breastfeeding; if used, infants should be monitored for cholinergic excess with symptoms such as diarrhea, lacrimation and excessive urination {[}21]. As such, nonpharmacologic management of PUR should be prioritized.Lastly, studies have also examined the use of acupuncture and the act of remedying imbalances of Qi, a concept of the vital force of life. Recent small studies involving acupuncture postpartum and auricular acupressure are protective against PUR {[}22,23].Urinary incontinence, encompassing stress, urge and mixed subtypes, is known to have a significant impact on quality of life {[}24]. It is estimated to impact 32-64\% of pregnancies and 15-30\% of individuals in the first year postpartum {[}25]. Risk factors for postpartum urinary incontinence include protracted second stage of labor, operative vaginal delivery, increased maternal parity, and larger fetal head circumference {[}4]. While physiologic factors such as intra-abdominal pressure from a gravid uterus may resolve with delivery, limited research exists regarding prevention and management of postpartum urinary incontinence.Additionally, surveys have shown that a majority of patients who report stress urinary incontinence (SUI) antepartum and 8 weeks postpartum had persistent symptoms 1 year postpartum, highlighting the symptom's high positive predictive value {[}26]. With knowledge that pregnancy is a strong risk factor for urinary incontinence and development of pregnancy urinary incontinence is strongly associated with persistent symptoms, improved management of postpartum urinary incontinence is necessary to reduce the burden it has on patients.Similar to PUR, postpartum urinary incontinence lacks standardized identification antepartum and postpartum. Studies have found that providers do not routinely screen for PFD or urinary incontinence complaints in the postpartum period {[}9]. Additionally, there is no postpartum-specific screening tool established {[}2,27,28]. Simple questions such as ``Do you experience bothersome leakage of urine?{''} may effectively screen patients and allow providers to avoid over-normalization of peripartum urinary incontinence {[}9]. This education helps prevent the patient perception that their urinary incontinence will improve spontaneously with time, an outcome which not every patient may experience {[}27].Lastly, frequent screening may also lead to improved outcomes through earlier diagnosis of urinary incontinence.In general, pregnancy-related urinary incontinence management should focus on conservative efforts including behavioral modifications and pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) with the option of including biofeedback. Behavioral modifications include maintaining appropriate bladder hygiene with limited bladder irritants and timed voids.Following education on behavioral modifications, PFMT is a first-line recommendation for management of stress and mixed urinary incontinence that remains well tolerated and effective in pregnant and postpartum patients {[}24]. A Cochrane review of 46 studies highlighted that early, structured antenatal PFMT reduced the risk of late pregnancy and postpartum urinary incontinence between 3 and 6 months postpartum in patients who were continent prior to pregnancy {[}29]. The ability for PFMT to both prevent and treat urinary incontinence may also be cost-effective; an additional meta-analysis found that antenatal PFMT continued to have risk-reduction for postnatal urinary incontinence {[}30]. This factor is important to consider while patients seek PFMT during their peripartum period, as many individuals must consider the cost of attending additional appointments antenatally. Studies have also found additional benefits of a simple antepartum PFMT regimen suggested by Woodley and Hay-Smith {[}31] as listed in Table 3, including improved sexual satisfaction, prevention anal insufficiency and also improving labor and delivery outcomes given overall increased strength and control of the pelvic floor musculature.Minimum PFMT exercise prescriptionPreviously published in Woodley and Hay-Smith {[}31].Pessaries and other vaginal inserts for SUI are additional well tolerated options for pregnant and postpartum patients. Postpartum-specific pessaries have shown improvement in urinary incontinence symptoms at both 3 and 6-month postpartum {[}32]. Specific postpartum pessaries such as the Restifem have been utilized as early as 6 weeks postpartum {[}32]. However, earlier use in a symptomatic patient could be considered for patients with minimal or no vaginal tearing from the obstetric delivery (including cesarean section) and would be at the discretion of the obstetric provider. While pharmacologic therapies such as antimuscarinics, beta-3 adrenergics and onabotulinum toxin are an option for overactive bladder, they are contraindicated if a patient is breastfeeding, limiting their clinical utility for refractory symptoms postpartum. Lastly, surgical procedures for significant, bothersome SUI are typically deferred until a patient heals completely from pregnancy, traditionally not before 6 months postpartum.In sum, maternal care providers should implement screening for urinary incontinence and offer either education on self-taught PFMT regimens or referrals to physical therapists for PFMT sessions. Future considerations may utilize telemedicine or mobile applications in order to make education regarding patient-driven PFMT available at a patient's convenience.When evaluating postpartum urinary incontinence, obstetric-related vesicovaginal fistulas (VVFs) may be considered. Although rare in developed countries, VVFs may occur in the setting of prolonged obstructed labor and often present 1-2 weeks after delivery {[}33]. Case reports also report a higher incidence of other genitourinary fistulas including vesicouterine fistulas in the setting of the increasing incidence of cesarean sections {[}34]. Thin lower uterine segments in conjunction with bladder adhesive disease and poor visualization of the vesicouterine flexure are likely the cause behind these rare fistulas {[}34]. Lastly, a handful of case reports have also highlighted genitourinary fistulas in the setting of uterine artery embolization for postpartum hemorrhage {[}35]. While all of these scenarios are rare, genitourinary fistulas must be considered if patients present with atypical symptoms such as continuous clear vaginal leakage. These typically can be clinically diagnosed with urine pooling in the vagina on a speculum examination; however, a double dye tampon test can be helpful if physical examination findings are equivocal. Additional imaging, such as a computed tomography (CT) urogram, is also important given the elevated incidence of concurrent vesicovaginal and ureterovaginal fistulas.Postpartum urinary dysfunction is a common sequalae during the immediate postpartum and fourth trimester periods. Simple modifications during recovery may reduce PUR risk. Using standardized PUR protocols allows for management in both the outpatient and inpatient settings and reduces the likelihood of bladder injury. Management of peripartum urinary incontinence necessitates early identification and utilization of conservative measures such as PFMT. Importantly, increased patient and provider education is imperative to raise awareness that bladder complaints should be standardly integrated in postpartum care.None.Purpose of reviewThe aim of this study was to describe the common postpartum urinary sequelae including urinary retention and incontinence, and to summarize the management of these conditions.Despite the high frequency of urinary disorders in obstetrics, screening and management protocols are rarely utilized by providers. Large variation exists in the literature regarding assessment of postpartum urinary retention, values of postvoid residuals and management of indwelling catheters in the immediate postpartum population. Recent expert guidance outlines a strategy for managing this condition.Research also highlights that screening for peripartum urinary incontinence is not a routine practice. The diagnosis is made more challenging by the fact that patients commonly understate and over-normalize their symptoms. Emerging studies have found that pelvic floor muscle training is cost-effective, preventive, and may improve symptoms in the postpartum setting.Increased awareness of urinary disorders in pregnancy and postpartum is imperative for appropriate diagnosis and management. Instituting standardized voiding protocols postpartum will allow providers to avoid undiagnosed postpartum urinary retention and its repercussions. Improved screening and education regarding urinary incontinence in the peripartum is important for early management, such as pelvic floor muscle training, and improved quality of life.Papers of particular interest, published within the annual period of review, have been highlighted as:While society places a large emphasis on antepartum obstetrical care, there continues to be insufficient patient education and awareness about the fourth trimester, or the first 12 weeks after giving birth, including the many short and long-term sequalae associated with delivery. Notably, education about peripartum pelvic floor disorders (PFDs) is often ignored during pregnancy, with studies finding that patients between the ages of 19 and 39 years were the least proficient regarding the topic {[}1]. PFDs are associated with decreased quality of life, psychological strain and a sense of patient embarrassment {[}2]. Out of the three domains of PFDs, urinary symptom distress is the most common in obstetrics, with 41.8\% of patients reporting these issues {[}2]. These symptoms may present at opposite ends of the spectrum during the postpartum period with urinary retention and urinary incontinence. As such, the purpose of this article is to educate providers on how to prevent, recognize and manage postpartum urinary sequelae. no caption availableGenitourinary system changes associated with pregnancy begin in the first trimester. The underlying mechanisms contributing to these dynamic changes are multifaceted. Elevation in the level of progesterone may lead to decreased urethral pressures, relaxation of urinary system smooth muscle and impaired detrusor contractility {[}3]. Renal changes include an increase in glomerular filtration rates and dilation of the ureters, resulting in increased urine production and functional bladder volumes. The enlarging gravid uterus contributes to bladder compression and can lead to urinary frequency, urgency and incontinence {[}2,4]. Together, these genitourinary system changes make bladder control issues a common phenomenon antepartum, and for some, persistent postpartum.Aspects of the birthing process are thought to predispose some individuals to the development of urinary disorders as well. Mechanical forces from pushing cause anatomical changes with inevitable bladder descent and compression. This may result in cellular injury, causing neurogenic dysfunction and consequently diminished sensation associated with bladder filling {[}5]. Lack of bladder sensation may lead to a vicious cycle where further overdistention of the bladder may in turn result in continued damage and reduced detrusor contractility.Epidurals and other forms of neuraxial anesthesia may also predispose individuals to postpartum voiding dysfunction due to disruption of afferent bladder innervations {[}6]. This disruption consequently interferes with the ability of the pontine micturition center to signal for detrusor muscle contraction and urethral sphincter relaxation {[}7].Traumatic birth processes such as perineal edema, advanced lacerations and hematomas may cause mechanical bladder outlet obstruction {[}6]. Other sources of birth trauma may involve levator ani muscle avulsion and nerve injury involving the pelvic, hypogastric and pudendal nerves which can affect sensation and continence {[}3,8]. Obstetric anal sphincter injuries and other lacerations may also impair reflexive and voluntary relaxation of the urethrae sphincter and periurethral muscles {[}3]. While these outcomes may be identified during a patient's postpartum care, their physiologic consequences also predispose patients to postpartum urinary retention (PUR) and urinary dysfunction, a diagnosis that may be more nuanced to identify.PUR is a relatively common postpartum phenomenon with a wide range of incidence in the literature, ranging from 1.5 to 45\% {[}9]. This large variance is likely due to a variety of reasons, including most importantly the lack of standardized definitions and management protocols for PUR. Consequently, only approximately 30\% of United States labor and delivery institutions have an established protocol for PUR evaluation and management, which thereby contributes to a wide variation in PUR recognition clinically {[}3].There are three main subtypes of PUR, outlined in Table 1. Individuals with PUR may present with symptoms similar to nonobstetric postoperative patients, including low urine output, frequency, dysuria, suprapubic fullness or hesitancy to void {[}3]. In an obstetric-specific clinical scenario, additional findings may include displaced fundal exams (both in height and in lateral displacement) and increased vaginal bleeding due to impaired ability for the uterus to contract down {[}3]. As implied by the definition of covert PUR, individuals may also be asymptomatic. A multitude of risk factors described in Table 2 may predispose certain individuals to PUR. As such, PUR may go undiagnosed if proper screening protocols are not in place.Subtypes of postpartum urinary retentionPUR, postpartum urinary retention.Risk factors for postpartum urinary retention {[}5,6,9,10]ISC, intermittent straight catheterization; OASIS, obstetric anal sphincter injuries.Importantly, mismanaged PUR may lead to rare long-term repercussions, including noncontractile fibrosis of the detrusor muscle and bladder rupture {[}3]. Previous research has shown that PUR may take up to 42 days to resolve, with some studies also reporting prolonged voiding dysfunction at intervals 1-3 years after delivery {[}8]. These findings stress the importance of both creating and utilizing a set of standardized recommendations to manage PUR.Early diagnosis is essential in PUR management. The amount of variation in the literature regarding PUR likely leads to decreased awareness and impaired diagnosis. While the previously described definitions in Table 1 are the most common established in the literature, it is notable that there is variance in the specific postvoid residual (PVR) cut-offs {[}5,10]. The most common PVR cut-off remains 150 ml, without consequent adverse outcomes with using this volume {[}11]. Given that values above 200 ml may reflect inadequate bladder emptying and values less than 100 ml may be a normal variant, 150 ml should remain the standard abnormal PVR cut-off.The route of measurement of PVRs varies greatly in the literature. A systemic review of PUR found the majority of studies used transabdominal ultrasounds or ultrasonic measurement devices (commonly known as a bladder scanner) to measure PVR rather than intermittent self-catheterization (ISC) {[}12]. While bladder scanners may be convenient and easy to use, there is evidence these devices in the postpartum period may have low accuracy with +/- 15\% error, leading to discrepancies averaging 42.7 ml between measuring modalities {[}12,13]. Alternatively, transabdominal ultrasound is costly, time-consuming and requires a qualified ultrasonographer {[}14]. Creation of a stepwise standardized protocol including first using bladder scanners and then performing ISC if an elevated PVR is identified may therefore prevent unnecessary invasive testing.There is also significant variation of indwelling catheter usage following delivery. A review found in patients who underwent cesarean section, removal of urinary catheters greater than 24 h postoperatively decreased the risk of urinary retention, while removal less than 6 h postoperatively was associated with decreased risk of UTI and decreased the length to first ambulation {[}15]. Conversely, a randomized controlled trial found patients diagnosed with PUR had significant shorter timeframes to PUR resolution when managed with ISC, with no difference in UTI rates or length of hospital stay between the two management modalities {[}16]. A study comparing bedpan use versus mobilizing to the toilet postpartum found significantly higher micturition rates in individuals who used the toilet versus the bedpan {[}17]. This highlights simple behavioral modifications during recovery can be protective against PUR. Integration of these findings to a patient's postpartum care, with the addition of patient education on good bladder hygiene, are simple interventions that may help prevent bladder dysfunction.Utilization of a standardized protocol such as that presented in Nutaitis et al.{[}3] (Fig. 1) would therefore integrate evidence-based recommendations into a regimented postpartum bladder protocol. The protocol recommends measuring the first two spontaneous voids after delivery and/or catheter removal to ensure appropriate bladder emptying. Additionally, the protocol highlights when and how PVRs should be performed and methods of bladder rest if PUR is diagnosed. Further testing, including active void trials, is also recommended to ensure a patient's PUR has resolved. This testing can be broadly utilized in both the inpatient and outpatient setting if a patient's symptoms do not resolve while admitted. Lastly, methods of outpatient management are suggested to include both ISC and indwelling catheter after educated patient shared decision making. As the majority of PUR cases resolve within 72 h, the protocol is best integrated into postpartum care units and its algorithmic nature makes it easy to follow.Postpartum bladder management protocol.Given only 17.1\% of surveyed Obstetrics and Gynecology residents reported receiving formal PUR training, the largest area for improvement is provider education {[}18]. Formal education increased the likelihood that trainees were able to identify concerning clinical scenarios suggestive of PUR. An additional auditing study found nurses overall had minimal training on identification and management of PUR {[}19]. This study audited criteria such as encouraging regular voids intrapartum, recording strict fluid input and output both in the intrapartum and postpartum period, and ensuring individuals had two adequate spontaneous voids after delivery. After educational strategies were implemented, the study found reductions in both PUR incidence and the time to void after delivery {[}19]. Taken together, healthcare provider education on PUR is effective for properly identifying and managing abnormal voiding patterns and is important for improving patient outcomes.Active patient management remains the most important strategy for PUR management. However, bethanechol is FDA approved for the PUR treatment {[}20]. Bethanechol acts by activating bladder muscarinic receptors, which increases detrusor muscle tone to aid in bladder emptying {[}20]. However, this agent has notable cardiac, pulmonary and gastrointestinal adverse effects which limit broad application. Additionally, there is no established literature regarding the usage of bethanechol while breastfeeding; if used, infants should be monitored for cholinergic excess with symptoms such as diarrhea, lacrimation and excessive urination {[}21]. As such, nonpharmacologic management of PUR should be prioritized.Lastly, studies have also examined the use of acupuncture and the act of remedying imbalances of Qi, a concept of the vital force of life. Recent small studies involving acupuncture postpartum and auricular acupressure are protective against PUR {[}22,23].Urinary incontinence, encompassing stress, urge and mixed subtypes, is known to have a significant impact on quality of life {[}24]. It is estimated to impact 32-64\% of pregnancies and 15-30\% of individuals in the first year postpartum {[}25]. Risk factors for postpartum urinary incontinence include protracted second stage of labor, operative vaginal delivery, increased maternal parity, and larger fetal head circumference {[}4]. While physiologic factors such as intra-abdominal pressure from a gravid uterus may resolve with delivery, limited research exists regarding prevention and management of postpartum urinary incontinence.Additionally, surveys have shown that a majority of patients who report stress urinary incontinence (SUI) antepartum and 8 weeks postpartum had persistent symptoms 1 year postpartum, highlighting the symptom's high positive predictive value {[}26]. With knowledge that pregnancy is a strong risk factor for urinary incontinence and development of pregnancy urinary incontinence is strongly associated with persistent symptoms, improved management of postpartum urinary incontinence is necessary to reduce the burden it has on patients.Similar to PUR, postpartum urinary incontinence lacks standardized identification antepartum and postpartum. Studies have found that providers do not routinely screen for PFD or urinary incontinence complaints in the postpartum period {[}9]. Additionally, there is no postpartum-specific screening tool established {[}2,27,28]. Simple questions such as ``Do you experience bothersome leakage of urine?{''} may effectively screen patients and allow providers to avoid over-normalization of peripartum urinary incontinence {[}9]. This education helps prevent the patient perception that their urinary incontinence will improve spontaneously with time, an outcome which not every patient may experience {[}27].Lastly, frequent screening may also lead to improved outcomes through earlier diagnosis of urinary incontinence.In general, pregnancy-related urinary incontinence management should focus on conservative efforts including behavioral modifications and pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) with the option of including biofeedback. Lastly, surgical procedures for significant, bothersome SUI are typically deferred until a patient heals completely from pregnancy, traditionally not before 6 months postpartum.In sum, maternal care providers should implement screening for urinary incontinence and offer either education on self-taught PFMT regimens or referrals to physical therapists for PFMT sessions. Future considerations may utilize telemedicine or mobile applications in order to make education regarding patient-driven PFMT available at a patient's convenience. When evaluating postpartum urinary incontinence, obstetric-related vesicovaginal fistulas (VVFs) may be considered. Although rare in developed countries, VVFs may occur in the setting of prolonged obstructed labor and often present 1-2 weeks after delivery {[}33]. Case reports also report a higher incidence of other genitourinary fistulas including vesicouterine fistulas in the setting of the increasing incidence of cesarean sections {[}34]. Thin lower uterine segments in conjunction with bladder adhesive disease and poor visualization of the vesicouterine flexure are likely the cause behind these rare fistulas {[}34]. Lastly, a handful of case reports have also highlighted genitourinary fistulas in the setting of uterine artery embolization for postpartum hemorrhage {[}35]. While all of these scenarios are rare, genitourinary fistulas must be considered if patients present with atypical symptoms such as continuous clear vaginal leakage. These typically can be clinically diagnosed with urine pooling in the vagina on a speculum examination; however, a double dye tampon test can be helpful if physical examination findings are equivocal. Additional imaging, such as a computed tomography (CT) urogram, is also important given the elevated incidence of concurrent vesicovaginal and ureterovaginal fistulas.Postpartum urinary dysfunction is a common sequalae during the immediate postpartum and fourth trimester periods. Simple modifications during recovery may reduce PUR risk. Using standardized PUR protocols allows for management in both the outpatient and inpatient settings and reduces the likelihood of bladder injury. Management of peripartum urinary incontinence necessitates early identification and utilization of conservative measures such as PFMT. Importantly, increased patient and provider education is imperative to raise awareness that bladder complaints should be standardly integrated in postpartum care.None.Purpose of reviewThe aim of this study was to describe the common postpartum urinary sequelae including urinary retention and incontinence, and to summarize the management of these conditions.Despite the high frequency of urinary disorders in obstetrics, screening and management protocols are rarely utilized by providers. Large variation exists in the literature regarding assessment of postpartum urinary retention, values of postvoid residuals and management of indwelling catheters in the immediate postpartum population. Recent expert guidance outlines a strategy for managing this condition.Research also highlights that screening for peripartum urinary incontinence is not a routine practice. The diagnosis is made more challenging by the fact that patients commonly understate and over-normalize their symptoms. Emerging studies have found that pelvic floor muscle training is cost-effective, preventive, and may improve symptoms in the postpartum setting.Increased awareness of urinary disorders in pregnancy and postpartum is imperative for appropriate diagnosis and management. Instituting standardized voiding protocols postpartum will allow providers to avoid undiagnosed postpartum urinary retention and its repercussions. Improved screening and education regarding urinary incontinence in the peripartum is important for early management, such as pelvic floor muscle training, and improved quality of life. Papers of particular interest, published within the annual period of review, have been highlighted as:While society places a large emphasis on antepartum obstetrical care, there continues to be insufficient patient education and awareness about the fourth trimester, or the first 12 weeks after giving birth, including the many short and long-term sequalae associated with delivery. Notably, education about peripartum pelvic floor disorders (PFDs) is often ignored during pregnancy, with studies finding that patients between the ages of 19 and 39 years were the least proficient regarding the topic {[}1]. PFDs are associated with decreased quality of life, psychological strain and a sense of patient embarrassment {[}2]. Out of the three domains of PFDs, urinary symptom distress is the most common in obstetrics, with 41.8\% of patients reporting these issues {[}2]. These symptoms may present at opposite ends of the spectrum during the postpartum period with urinary retention and urinary incontinence. As such, the purpose of this article is to educate providers on how to prevent, recognize and manage postpartum urinary sequelae. no caption availableGenitourinary system changes associated with pregnancy begin in the first trimester. The underlying mechanisms contributing to these dynamic changes are multifaceted. Elevation in the level of progesterone may lead to decreased urethral pressures, relaxation of urinary system smooth muscle and impaired detrusor contractility {[}3]. Renal changes include an increase in glomerular filtration rates and dilation of the ureters, resulting in increased urine production and functional bladder volumes. The enlarging gravid uterus contributes to bladder compression and can lead to urinary frequency, urgency and incontinence {[}2,4]. Together, these genitourinary system changes make bladder control issues a common phenomenon antepartum, and for some, persistent postpartum.Aspects of the birthing process are thought to predispose some individuals to the development of urinary disorders as well. Mechanical forces from pushing cause anatomical changes with inevitable bladder descent and compression. This may result in cellular injury, causing neurogenic dysfunction and consequently diminished sensation associated with bladder filling {[}5]. Lack of bladder sensation may lead to a vicious cycle where further overdistention of the bladder may in turn result in continued damage and reduced detrusor contractility.Epidurals and other forms of neuraxial anesthesia may also predispose individuals to postpartum voiding dysfunction due to disruption of afferent bladder innervations {[}6]. This disruption consequently interferes with the ability of the pontine micturition center to signal for detrusor muscle contraction and urethral sphincter relaxation {[}7].Traumatic birth processes such as perineal edema, advanced lacerations and hematomas may cause mechanical bladder outlet obstruction {[}6]. Other sources of birth trauma may involve levator ani muscle avulsion and nerve injury involving the pelvic, hypogastric and pudendal nerves which can affect sensation and continence {[}3,8]. Obstetric anal sphincter injuries and other lacerations may also impair reflexive and voluntary relaxation of the urethrae sphincter and periurethral muscles {[}3]. While these outcomes may be identified during a patient's postpartum care, their physiologic consequences also predispose patients to postpartum urinary retention (PUR) and urinary dysfunction, a diagnosis that may be more nuanced to identify. PUR is a relatively common postpartum phenomenon with a wide range of incidence in the literature, ranging from 1.5 to 45\% {[}9]. This large variance is likely due to a variety of reasons, including most importantly the lack of standardized definitions and management protocols for PUR. Consequently, only approximately 30\% of United States labor and delivery institutions have an established protocol for PUR evaluation and management, which thereby contributes to a wide variation in PUR recognition clinically {[}3].There are three main subtypes of PUR, outlined in Table 1. Individuals with PUR may present with symptoms similar to nonobstetric postoperative patients, including low urine output, frequency, dysuria, suprapubic fullness or hesitancy to void {[}3]. In an obstetric-specific clinical scenario, additional findings may include displaced fundal exams (both in height and in lateral displacement) and increased vaginal bleeding due to impaired ability for the uterus to contract down {[}3]. As implied by the definition of covert PUR, individuals may also be asymptomatic. A multitude of risk factors described in Table 2 may predispose certain individuals to PUR. As such, PUR may go undiagnosed if proper screening protocols are not in place.Subtypes of postpartum urinary retentionPUR, postpartum urinary retention.Risk factors for postpartum urinary retention {[}5,6,9,10]ISC, intermittent straight catheterization; OASIS, obstetric anal sphincter injuries.Importantly, mismanaged PUR may lead to rare long-term repercussions, including noncontractile fibrosis of the detrusor muscle and bladder rupture {[}3]. Previous research has shown that PUR may take up to 42 days to resolve, with some studies also reporting prolonged voiding dysfunction at intervals 1-3 years after delivery {[}8]. These findings stress the importance of both creating and utilizing a set of standardized recommendations to manage PUR.Early diagnosis is essential in PUR management. The amount of variation in the literature regarding PUR likely leads to decreased awareness and impaired diagnosis. While the previously described definitions in Table 1 are the most common established in the literature, it is notable that there is variance in the specific postvoid residual (PVR) cut-offs {[}5,10]. The most common PVR cut-off remains 150 ml, without consequent adverse outcomes with using this volume {[}11]. Given that values above 200 ml may reflect inadequate bladder emptying and values less than 100 ml may be a normal variant, 150 ml should remain the standard abnormal PVR cut-off.The route of measurement of PVRs varies greatly in the literature. A systemic review of PUR found the majority of studies used transabdominal ultrasounds or ultrasonic measurement devices (commonly known as a bladder scanner) to measure PVR rather than intermittent self-catheterization (ISC) {[}12]. While bladder scanners may be convenient and easy to use, there is evidence these devices in the postpartum period may have low accuracy with +/- 15\% error, leading to discrepancies averaging 42.7 ml between measuring modalities {[}12,13]. Alternatively, transabdominal ultrasound is costly, time-consuming and requires a qualified ultrasonographer {[}14]. Creation of a stepwise standardized protocol including first using bladder scanners and then performing ISC if an elevated PVR is identified may therefore prevent unnecessary invasive testing.There is also significant variation of indwelling catheter usage following delivery. A review found in patients who underwent cesarean section, removal of urinary catheters greater than 24 h postoperatively decreased the risk of urinary retention, while removal less than 6 h postoperatively was associated with decreased risk of UTI and decreased the length to first ambulation {[}15]. Conversely, a randomized controlled trial found patients diagnosed with PUR had significant shorter timeframes to PUR resolution when managed with ISC, with no difference in UTI rates or length of hospital stay between the two management modalities {[}16]. A study comparing bedpan use versus mobilizing to the toilet postpartum found significantly higher micturition rates in individuals who used the toilet versus the bedpan {[}17]. This highlights simple behavioral modifications during recovery can be protective against PUR. Integration of these findings to a patient's postpartum care, with the addition of patient education on good bladder hygiene, are simple interventions that may help prevent bladder dysfunction.Utilization of a standardized protocol such as that presented in Nutaitis et al.{[}3] (Fig. 1) would therefore integrate evidence-based recommendations into a regimented postpartum bladder protocol. The protocol recommends measuring the first two spontaneous voids after delivery and/or catheter removal to ensure appropriate bladder emptying. Additionally, the protocol highlights when and how PVRs should be performed and methods of bladder rest if PUR is diagnosed. Further testing, including active void trials, is also recommended to ensure a patient's PUR has resolved. This testing can be broadly utilized in both the inpatient and outpatient setting if a patient's symptoms do not resolve while admitted. Lastly, methods of outpatient management are suggested to include both ISC and indwelling catheter after educated patient shared decision making. As the majority of PUR cases resolve within 72 h, the protocol is best integrated into postpartum care units and its algorithmic nature makes it easy to follow.Postpartum bladder management protocol.Given only 17.1\% of surveyed Obstetrics and Gynecology residents reported receiving formal PUR training, the largest area for improvement is provider education {[}18]. Formal education increased the likelihood that trainees were able to identify concerning clinical scenarios suggestive of PUR. An additional auditing study found nurses overall had minimal training on identification and management of PUR {[}19]. This study audited criteria such as encouraging regular voids intrapartum, recording strict fluid input and output both in the intrapartum and postpartum period, and ensuring individuals had two adequate spontaneous voids after delivery. After educational strategies were implemented, the study found reductions in both PUR incidence and the time to void after delivery {[}19]. Taken together, healthcare provider education on PUR is effective for properly identifying and managing abnormal voiding patterns and is important for improving patient outcomes.Active patient management remains the most important strategy for PUR management. However, bethanechol is FDA approved for the PUR treatment {[}20]. Bethanechol acts by activating bladder muscarinic receptors, which increases detrusor muscle tone to aid in bladder emptying {[}20]. However, this agent has notable cardiac, pulmonary and gastrointestinal adverse effects which limit broad application. Additionally, there is no established literature regarding the usage of bethanechol while breastfeeding; if used, infants should be monitored for cholinergic excess with symptoms such as diarrhea, lacrimation and excessive urination {[}21]. As such, nonpharmacologic management of PUR should be prioritized.Lastly, studies have also examined the use of acupuncture and the act of remedying imbalances of Qi, a concept of the vital force of life. Recent small studies involving acupuncture postpartum and auricular acupressure are protective against PUR {[}22,23].Urinary incontinence, encompassing stress, urge and mixed subtypes, is known to have a significant impact on quality of life {[}24]. It is estimated to impact 32-64\% of pregnancies and 15-30\% of individuals in the first year postpartum {[}25]. Risk factors for postpartum urinary incontinence include protracted second stage of labor, operative vaginal delivery, increased maternal parity, and larger fetal head circumference {[}4]. While physiologic factors such as intra-abdominal pressure from a gravid uterus may resolve with delivery, limited research exists regarding prevention and management of postpartum urinary incontinence.Additionally, surveys have shown that a majority of patients who report stress urinary incontinence (SUI) antepartum and 8 weeks postpartum had persistent symptoms 1 year postpartum, highlighting the symptom's high positive predictive value {[}26]. With knowledge that pregnancy is a strong risk factor for urinary incontinence and development of pregnancy urinary incontinence is strongly associated with persistent symptoms, improved management of postpartum urinary incontinence is necessary to reduce the burden it has on patients.Similar to PUR, postpartum urinary incontinence lacks standardized identification antepartum and postpartum. Studies have found that providers do not routinely screen for PFD or urinary incontinence complaints in the postpartum period {[}9]. Additionally, there is no postpartum-specific screening tool established {[}2,27,28]. Simple questions such as ``Do you experience bothersome leakage of urine?{''} may effectively screen patients and allow providers to avoid over-normalization of peripartum urinary incontinence {[}9]. This education helps prevent the patient perception that their urinary incontinence will improve spontaneously with time, an outcome which not every patient may experience {[}27].Lastly, frequent screening may also lead to improved outcomes through earlier diagnosis of urinary incontinence.In general, pregnancy-related urinary incontinence management should focus on conservative efforts including behavioral modifications and pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) with the option of including biofeedback. Behavioral modifications include maintaining appropriate bladder hygiene with limited bladder irritants and timed voids.Following education on behavioral modifications, PFMT is a first-line recommendation for management of stress and mixed urinary incontinence that remains well tolerated and effective in pregnant and postpartum patients {[}24]. A Cochrane review of 46 studies highlighted that early, structured antenatal PFMT reduced the risk of late pregnancy and postpartum urinary incontinence between 3 and 6 months postpartum in patients who were continent prior to pregnancy {[}29]. The ability for PFMT to both prevent and treat urinary incontinence may also be cost-effective; an additional meta-analysis found that antenatal PFMT continued to have risk-reduction for postnatal urinary incontinence {[}30]. This factor is important to consider while patients seek PFMT during their peripartum period, as many individuals must consider the cost of attending additional appointments antenatally. Studies have also found additional benefits of a simple antepartum PFMT regimen suggested by Woodley and Hay-Smith {[}31] as listed in Table 3, including improved sexual satisfaction, prevention anal insufficiency and also improving labor and delivery outcomes given overall increased strength and control of the pelvic floor musculature.Minimum PFMT exercise prescriptionPreviously published in Woodley and Hay-Smith {[}31].Pessaries and other vaginal inserts for SUI are additional well tolerated options for pregnant and postpartum patients. Postpartum-specific pessaries have shown improvement in urinary incontinence symptoms at both 3 and 6-month postpartum {[}32]. Specific postpartum pessaries such as the Restifem have been utilized as early as 6 weeks postpartum {[}32]. However, earlier use in a symptomatic patient could be considered for patients with minimal or no vaginal tearing from the obstetric delivery (including cesarean section) and would be at the discretion of the obstetric provider. While pharmacologic therapies such as antimuscarinics, beta-3 adrenergics and onabotulinum toxin are an option for overactive bladder, they are contraindicated if a patient is breastfeeding, limiting their clinical utility for refractory symptoms postpartum.
