Instituting standardized voiding protocols postpartum will allow providers to avoid undiagnosed postpartum urinary retention and its repercussions. Improved screening and education regarding urinary incontinence in the peripartum is important for early management, such as pelvic floor muscle training, and improved quality of life.Papers of particular interest, published within the annual period of review, have been highlighted as:While society places a large emphasis on antepartum obstetrical care, there continues to be insufficient patient education and awareness about the fourth trimester, or the first 12 weeks after giving birth, including the many short and long-term sequalae associated with delivery. Notably, education about peripartum pelvic floor disorders (PFDs) is often ignored during pregnancy, with studies finding that patients between the ages of 19 and 39 years were the least proficient regarding the topic {[}1]. PFDs are associated with decreased quality of life, psychological strain and a sense of patient embarrassment {[}2]. Out of the three domains of PFDs, urinary symptom distress is the most common in obstetrics, with 41.8\% of patients reporting these issues {[}2]. These symptoms may present at opposite ends of the spectrum during the postpartum period with urinary retention and urinary incontinence. As such, the purpose of this article is to educate providers on how to prevent, recognize and manage postpartum urinary sequelae. no caption availableGenitourinary system changes associated with pregnancy begin in the first trimester. The underlying mechanisms contributing to these dynamic changes are multifaceted. Elevation in the level of progesterone may lead to decreased urethral pressures, relaxation of urinary system smooth muscle and impaired detrusor contractility {[}3]. Renal changes include an increase in glomerular filtration rates and dilation of the ureters, resulting in increased urine production and functional bladder volumes. The enlarging gravid uterus contributes to bladder compression and can lead to urinary frequency, urgency and incontinence {[}2,4]. Together, these genitourinary system changes make bladder control issues a common phenomenon antepartum, and for some, persistent postpartum.Aspects of the birthing process are thought to predispose some individuals to the development of urinary disorders as well. Mechanical forces from pushing cause anatomical changes with inevitable bladder descent and compression. This may result in cellular injury, causing neurogenic dysfunction and consequently diminished sensation associated with bladder filling {[}5]. Lack of bladder sensation may lead to a vicious cycle where further overdistention of the bladder may in turn result in continued damage and reduced detrusor contractility.Epidurals and other forms of neuraxial anesthesia may also predispose individuals to postpartum voiding dysfunction due to disruption of afferent bladder innervations {[}6]. This disruption consequently interferes with the ability of the pontine micturition center to signal for detrusor muscle contraction and urethral sphincter relaxation {[}7].Traumatic birth processes such as perineal edema, advanced lacerations and hematomas may cause mechanical bladder outlet obstruction {[}6]. Other sources of birth trauma may involve levator ani muscle avulsion and nerve injury involving the pelvic, hypogastric and pudendal nerves which can affect sensation and continence {[}3,8]. Obstetric anal sphincter injuries and other lacerations may also impair reflexive and voluntary relaxation of the urethrae sphincter and periurethral muscles {[}3]. While these outcomes may be identified during a patient's postpartum care, their physiologic consequences also predispose patients to postpartum urinary retention (PUR) and urinary dysfunction, a diagnosis that may be more nuanced to identify.PUR is a relatively common postpartum phenomenon with a wide range of incidence in the literature, ranging from 1.5 to 45\% {[}9]. This large variance is likely due to a variety of reasons, including most importantly the lack of standardized definitions and management protocols for PUR. Consequently, only approximately 30\% of United States labor and delivery institutions have an established protocol for PUR evaluation and management, which thereby contributes to a wide variation in PUR recognition clinically {[}3].There are three main subtypes of PUR, outlined in Table 1. Individuals with PUR may present with symptoms similar to nonobstetric postoperative patients, including low urine output, frequency, dysuria, suprapubic fullness or hesitancy to void {[}3]. In an obstetric-specific clinical scenario, additional findings may include displaced fundal exams (both in height and in lateral displacement) and increased vaginal bleeding due to impaired ability for the uterus to contract down {[}3]. As implied by the definition of covert PUR, individuals may also be asymptomatic. A multitude of risk factors described in Table 2 may predispose certain individuals to PUR. As such, PUR may go undiagnosed if proper screening protocols are not in place.Subtypes of postpartum urinary retentionPUR, postpartum urinary retention.Risk factors for postpartum urinary retention {[}5,6,9,10]ISC, intermittent straight catheterization; OASIS, obstetric anal sphincter injuries. Importantly, mismanaged PUR may lead to rare long-term repercussions, including noncontractile fibrosis of the detrusor muscle and bladder rupture {[}3]. Previous research has shown that PUR may take up to 42 days to resolve, with some studies also reporting prolonged voiding dysfunction at intervals 1-3 years after delivery {[}8]. These findings stress the importance of both creating and utilizing a set of standardized recommendations to manage PUR.Early diagnosis is essential in PUR management. The amount of variation in the literature regarding PUR likely leads to decreased awareness and impaired diagnosis. While the previously described definitions in Table 1 are the most common established in the literature, it is notable that there is variance in the specific postvoid residual (PVR) cut-offs {[}5,10]. The most common PVR cut-off remains 150 ml, without consequent adverse outcomes with using this volume {[}11]. Given that values above 200 ml may reflect inadequate bladder emptying and values less than 100 ml may be a normal variant, 150 ml should remain the standard abnormal PVR cut-off.The route of measurement of PVRs varies greatly in the literature. A systemic review of PUR found the majority of studies used transabdominal ultrasounds or ultrasonic measurement devices (commonly known as a bladder scanner) to measure PVR rather than intermittent self-catheterization (ISC) {[}12]. While bladder scanners may be convenient and easy to use, there is evidence these devices in the postpartum period may have low accuracy with +/- 15\% error, leading to discrepancies averaging 42.7 ml between measuring modalities {[}12,13]. Alternatively, transabdominal ultrasound is costly, time-consuming and requires a qualified ultrasonographer {[}14]. Creation of a stepwise standardized protocol including first using bladder scanners and then performing ISC if an elevated PVR is identified may therefore prevent unnecessary invasive testing.There is also significant variation of indwelling catheter usage following delivery. A review found in patients who underwent cesarean section, removal of urinary catheters greater than 24 h postoperatively decreased the risk of urinary retention, while removal less than 6 h postoperatively was associated with decreased risk of UTI and decreased the length to first ambulation {[}15]. Conversely, a randomized controlled trial found patients diagnosed with PUR had significant shorter timeframes to PUR resolution when managed with ISC, with no difference in UTI rates or length of hospital stay between the two management modalities {[}16]. A study comparing bedpan use versus mobilizing to the toilet postpartum found significantly higher micturition rates in individuals who used the toilet versus the bedpan {[}17]. This highlights simple behavioral modifications during recovery can be protective against PUR. Integration of these findings to a patient's postpartum care, with the addition of patient education on good bladder hygiene, are simple interventions that may help prevent bladder dysfunction.Utilization of a standardized protocol such as that presented in Nutaitis et al.{[}3] (Fig. 1) would therefore integrate evidence-based recommendations into a regimented postpartum bladder protocol. The protocol recommends measuring the first two spontaneous voids after delivery and/or catheter removal to ensure appropriate bladder emptying. Additionally, the protocol highlights when and how PVRs should be performed and methods of bladder rest if PUR is diagnosed. Further testing, including active void trials, is also recommended to ensure a patient's PUR has resolved. This testing can be broadly utilized in both the inpatient and outpatient setting if a patient's symptoms do not resolve while admitted. Lastly, methods of outpatient management are suggested to include both ISC and indwelling catheter after educated patient shared decision making. As the majority of PUR cases resolve within 72 h, the protocol is best integrated into postpartum care units and its algorithmic nature makes it easy to follow.Postpartum bladder management protocol.Given only 17.1\% of surveyed Obstetrics and Gynecology residents reported receiving formal PUR training, the largest area for improvement is provider education {[}18]. Formal education increased the likelihood that trainees were able to identify concerning clinical scenarios suggestive of PUR. An additional auditing study found nurses overall had minimal training on identification and management of PUR {[}19]. This study audited criteria such as encouraging regular voids intrapartum, recording strict fluid input and output both in the intrapartum and postpartum period, and ensuring individuals had two adequate spontaneous voids after delivery. After educational strategies were implemented, the study found reductions in both PUR incidence and the time to void after delivery {[}19]. Taken together, healthcare provider education on PUR is effective for properly identifying and managing abnormal voiding patterns and is important for improving patient outcomes.Active patient management remains the most important strategy for PUR management. However, bethanechol is FDA approved for the PUR treatment {[}20]. Bethanechol acts by activating bladder muscarinic receptors, which increases detrusor muscle tone to aid in bladder emptying {[}20]. However, this agent has notable cardiac, pulmonary and gastrointestinal adverse effects which limit broad application. Additionally, there is no established literature regarding the usage of bethanechol while breastfeeding; if used, infants should be monitored for cholinergic excess with symptoms such as diarrhea, lacrimation and excessive urination {[}21]. As such, nonpharmacologic management of PUR should be prioritized.Lastly, studies have also examined the use of acupuncture and the act of remedying imbalances of Qi, a concept of the vital force of life. Recent small studies involving acupuncture postpartum and auricular acupressure are protective against PUR {[}22,23].Urinary incontinence, encompassing stress, urge and mixed subtypes, is known to have a significant impact on quality of life {[}24]. It is estimated to impact 32-64\% of pregnancies and 15-30\% of individuals in the first year postpartum {[}25]. Risk factors for postpartum urinary incontinence include protracted second stage of labor, operative vaginal delivery, increased maternal parity, and larger fetal head circumference {[}4]. While physiologic factors such as intra-abdominal pressure from a gravid uterus may resolve with delivery, limited research exists regarding prevention and management of postpartum urinary incontinence.Additionally, surveys have shown that a majority of patients who report stress urinary incontinence (SUI) antepartum and 8 weeks postpartum had persistent symptoms 1 year postpartum, highlighting the symptom's high positive predictive value {[}26]. With knowledge that pregnancy is a strong risk factor for urinary incontinence and development of pregnancy urinary incontinence is strongly associated with persistent symptoms, improved management of postpartum urinary incontinence is necessary to reduce the burden it has on patients.Similar to PUR, postpartum urinary incontinence lacks standardized identification antepartum and postpartum. Studies have found that providers do not routinely screen for PFD or urinary incontinence complaints in the postpartum period {[}9]. Additionally, there is no postpartum-specific screening tool established {[}2,27,28]. Simple questions such as ``Do you experience bothersome leakage of urine?{''} may effectively screen patients and allow providers to avoid over-normalization of peripartum urinary incontinence {[}9]. This education helps prevent the patient perception that their urinary incontinence will improve spontaneously with time, an outcome which not every patient may experience {[}27].Lastly, frequent screening may also lead to improved outcomes through earlier diagnosis of urinary incontinence.In general, pregnancy-related urinary incontinence management should focus on conservative efforts including behavioral modifications and pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) with the option of including biofeedback. Behavioral modifications include maintaining appropriate bladder hygiene with limited bladder irritants and timed voids.Following education on behavioral modifications, PFMT is a first-line recommendation for management of stress and mixed urinary incontinence that remains well tolerated and effective in pregnant and postpartum patients {[}24]. A Cochrane review of 46 studies highlighted that early, structured antenatal PFMT reduced the risk of late pregnancy and postpartum urinary incontinence between 3 and 6 months postpartum in patients who were continent prior to pregnancy {[}29]. The ability for PFMT to both prevent and treat urinary incontinence may also be cost-effective; an additional meta-analysis found that antenatal PFMT continued to have risk-reduction for postnatal urinary incontinence {[}30]. This factor is important to consider while patients seek PFMT during their peripartum period, as many individuals must consider the cost of attending additional appointments antenatally. Studies have also found additional benefits of a simple antepartum PFMT regimen suggested by Woodley and Hay-Smith {[}31] as listed in Table 3, including improved sexual satisfaction, prevention anal insufficiency and also improving labor and delivery outcomes given overall increased strength and control of the pelvic floor musculature.Minimum PFMT exercise prescriptionPreviously published in Woodley and Hay-Smith {[}31].Pessaries and other vaginal inserts for SUI are additional well tolerated options for pregnant and postpartum patients. Postpartum-specific pessaries have shown improvement in urinary incontinence symptoms at both 3 and 6-month postpartum {[}32]. Specific postpartum pessaries such as the Restifem have been utilized as early as 6 weeks postpartum {[}32]. However, earlier use in a symptomatic patient could be considered for patients with minimal or no vaginal tearing from the obstetric delivery (including cesarean section) and would be at the discretion of the obstetric provider. While pharmacologic therapies such as antimuscarinics, beta-3 adrenergics and onabotulinum toxin are an option for overactive bladder, they are contraindicated if a patient is breastfeeding, limiting their clinical utility for refractory symptoms postpartum. Lastly, surgical procedures for significant, bothersome SUI are typically deferred until a patient heals completely from pregnancy, traditionally not before 6 months postpartum.In sum, maternal care providers should implement screening for urinary incontinence and offer either education on self-taught PFMT regimens or referrals to physical therapists for PFMT sessions. Future considerations may utilize telemedicine or mobile applications in order to make education regarding patient-driven PFMT available at a patient's convenience.When evaluating postpartum urinary incontinence, obstetric-related vesicovaginal fistulas (VVFs) may be considered. Although rare in developed countries, VVFs may occur in the setting of prolonged obstructed labor and often present 1-2 weeks after delivery {[}33]. Case reports also report a higher incidence of other genitourinary fistulas including vesicouterine fistulas in the setting of the increasing incidence of cesarean sections {[}34]. Thin lower uterine segments in conjunction with bladder adhesive disease and poor visualization of the vesicouterine flexure are likely the cause behind these rare fistulas {[}34]. Lastly, a handful of case reports have also highlighted genitourinary fistulas in the setting of uterine artery embolization for postpartum hemorrhage {[}35]. While all of these scenarios are rare, genitourinary fistulas must be considered if patients present with atypical symptoms such as continuous clear vaginal leakage. These typically can be clinically diagnosed with urine pooling in the vagina on a speculum examination; however, a double dye tampon test can be helpful if physical examination findings are equivocal. Additional imaging, such as a computed tomography (CT) urogram, is also important given the elevated incidence of concurrent vesicovaginal and ureterovaginal fistulas.Postpartum urinary dysfunction is a common sequalae during the immediate postpartum and fourth trimester periods. Simple modifications during recovery may reduce PUR risk. Using standardized PUR protocols allows for management in both the outpatient and inpatient settings and reduces the likelihood of bladder injury. Management of peripartum urinary incontinence necessitates early identification and utilization of conservative measures such as PFMT. Importantly, increased patient and provider education is imperative to raise awareness that bladder complaints should be standardly integrated in postpartum care.None.Purpose of reviewThe aim of this study was to describe the common postpartum urinary sequelae including urinary retention and incontinence, and to summarize the management of these conditions.Despite the high frequency of urinary disorders in obstetrics, screening and management protocols are rarely utilized by providers. Recent expert guidance outlines a strategy for managing this condition.Research also highlights that screening for peripartum urinary incontinence is not a routine practice. Renal changes include an increase in glomerular filtration rates and dilation of the ureters, resulting in increased urine production and functional bladder volumes. The enlarging gravid uterus contributes to bladder compression and can lead to urinary frequency, urgency and incontinence {[}2,4]. Together, these genitourinary system changes make bladder control issues a common phenomenon antepartum, and for some, persistent postpartum.Aspects of the birthing process are thought to predispose some individuals to the development of urinary disorders as well. Mechanical forces from pushing cause anatomical changes with inevitable bladder descent and compression. This may result in cellular injury, causing neurogenic dysfunction and consequently diminished sensation associated with bladder filling {[}5]. Lack of bladder sensation may lead to a vicious cycle where further overdistention of the bladder may in turn result in continued damage and reduced detrusor contractility.Epidurals and other forms of neuraxial anesthesia may also predispose individuals to postpartum voiding dysfunction due to disruption of afferent bladder innervations {[}6]. This disruption consequently interferes with the ability of the pontine micturition center to signal for detrusor muscle contraction and urethral sphincter relaxation {[}7].Traumatic birth processes such as perineal edema, advanced lacerations and hematomas may cause mechanical bladder outlet obstruction {[}6]. Other sources of birth trauma may involve levator ani muscle avulsion and nerve injury involving the pelvic, hypogastric and pudendal nerves which can affect sensation and continence {[}3,8]. Obstetric anal sphincter injuries and other lacerations may also impair reflexive and voluntary relaxation of the urethrae sphincter and periurethral muscles {[}3]. While these outcomes may be identified during a patient's postpartum care, their physiologic consequences also predispose patients to postpartum urinary retention (PUR) and urinary dysfunction, a diagnosis that may be more nuanced to identify.PUR is a relatively common postpartum phenomenon with a wide range of incidence in the literature, ranging from 1.5 to 45\% {[}9]. This large variance is likely due to a variety of reasons, including most importantly the lack of standardized definitions and management protocols for PUR. Consequently, only approximately 30\% of United States labor and delivery institutions have an established protocol for PUR evaluation and management, which thereby contributes to a wide variation in PUR recognition clinically {[}3].There are three main subtypes of PUR, outlined in Table 1. Individuals with PUR may present with symptoms similar to nonobstetric postoperative patients, including low urine output, frequency, dysuria, suprapubic fullness or hesitancy to void {[}3]. In an obstetric-specific clinical scenario, additional findings may include displaced fundal exams (both in height and in lateral displacement) and increased vaginal bleeding due to impaired ability for the uterus to contract down {[}3]. As implied by the definition of covert PUR, individuals may also be asymptomatic. A multitude of risk factors described in Table 2 may predispose certain individuals to PUR. As such, PUR may go undiagnosed if proper screening protocols are not in place.Subtypes of postpartum urinary retentionPUR, postpartum urinary retention.Risk factors for postpartum urinary retention {[}5,6,9,10]ISC, intermittent straight catheterization; OASIS, obstetric anal sphincter injuries. Importantly, mismanaged PUR may lead to rare long-term repercussions, including noncontractile fibrosis of the detrusor muscle and bladder rupture {[}3]. Previous research has shown that PUR may take up to 42 days to resolve, with some studies also reporting prolonged voiding dysfunction at intervals 1-3 years after delivery {[}8]. These findings stress the importance of both creating and utilizing a set of standardized recommendations to manage PUR.Early diagnosis is essential in PUR management. The amount of variation in the literature regarding PUR likely leads to decreased awareness and impaired diagnosis. While the previously described definitions in Table 1 are the most common established in the literature, it is notable that there is variance in the specific postvoid residual (PVR) cut-offs {[}5,10]. The most common PVR cut-off remains 150 ml, without consequent adverse outcomes with using this volume {[}11]. Given that values above 200 ml may reflect inadequate bladder emptying and values less than 100 ml may be a normal variant, 150 ml should remain the standard abnormal PVR cut-off.The route of measurement of PVRs varies greatly in the literature. A systemic review of PUR found the majority of studies used transabdominal ultrasounds or ultrasonic measurement devices (commonly known as a bladder scanner) to measure PVR rather than intermittent self-catheterization (ISC) {[}12]. While bladder scanners may be convenient and easy to use, there is evidence these devices in the postpartum period may have low accuracy with +/- 15\% error, leading to discrepancies averaging 42.7 ml between measuring modalities {[}12,13]. Alternatively, transabdominal ultrasound is costly, time-consuming and requires a qualified ultrasonographer {[}14]. Creation of a stepwise standardized protocol including first using bladder scanners and then performing ISC if an elevated PVR is identified may therefore prevent unnecessary invasive testing.There is also significant variation of indwelling catheter usage following delivery. A review found in patients who underwent cesarean section, removal of urinary catheters greater than 24 h postoperatively decreased the risk of urinary retention, while removal less than 6 h postoperatively was associated with decreased risk of UTI and decreased the length to first ambulation {[}15]. Conversely, a randomized controlled trial found patients diagnosed with PUR had significant shorter timeframes to PUR resolution when managed with ISC, with no difference in UTI rates or length of hospital stay between the two management modalities {[}16]. A study comparing bedpan use versus mobilizing to the toilet postpartum found significantly higher micturition rates in individuals who used the toilet versus the bedpan {[}17]. This highlights simple behavioral modifications during recovery can be protective against PUR. Integration of these findings to a patient's postpartum care, with the addition of patient education on good bladder hygiene, are simple interventions that may help prevent bladder dysfunction.Utilization of a standardized protocol such as that presented in Nutaitis et al.{[}3] (Fig. 1) would therefore integrate evidence-based recommendations into a regimented postpartum bladder protocol. The protocol recommends measuring the first two spontaneous voids after delivery and/or catheter removal to ensure appropriate bladder emptying. Additionally, the protocol highlights when and how PVRs should be performed and methods of bladder rest if PUR is diagnosed. Further testing, including active void trials, is also recommended to ensure a patient's PUR has resolved. This testing can be broadly utilized in both the inpatient and outpatient setting if a patient's symptoms do not resolve while admitted. Lastly, methods of outpatient management are suggested to include both ISC and indwelling catheter after educated patient shared decision making. As the majority of PUR cases resolve within 72 h, the protocol is best integrated into postpartum care units and its algorithmic nature makes it easy to follow.Postpartum bladder management protocol.Given only 17.1\% of surveyed Obstetrics and Gynecology residents reported receiving formal PUR training, the largest area for improvement is provider education {[}18]. Formal education increased the likelihood that trainees were able to identify concerning clinical scenarios suggestive of PUR. An additional auditing study found nurses overall had minimal training on identification and management of PUR {[}19]. This study audited criteria such as encouraging regular voids intrapartum, recording strict fluid input and output both in the intrapartum and postpartum period, and ensuring individuals had two adequate spontaneous voids after delivery. After educational strategies were implemented, the study found reductions in both PUR incidence and the time to void after delivery {[}19]. Taken together, healthcare provider education on PUR is effective for properly identifying and managing abnormal voiding patterns and is important for improving patient outcomes.Active patient management remains the most important strategy for PUR management. However, bethanechol is FDA approved for the PUR treatment {[}20]. Bethanechol acts by activating bladder muscarinic receptors, which increases detrusor muscle tone to aid in bladder emptying {[}20]. However, this agent has notable cardiac, pulmonary and gastrointestinal adverse effects which limit broad application. Additionally, there is no established literature regarding the usage of bethanechol while breastfeeding; if used, infants should be monitored for cholinergic excess with symptoms such as diarrhea, lacrimation and excessive urination {[}21]. As such, nonpharmacologic management of PUR should be prioritized.Lastly, studies have also examined the use of acupuncture and the act of remedying imbalances of Qi, a concept of the vital force of life. Recent small studies involving acupuncture postpartum and auricular acupressure are protective against PUR {[}22,23].Urinary incontinence, encompassing stress, urge and mixed subtypes, is known to have a significant impact on quality of life {[}24]. It is estimated to impact 32-64\% of pregnancies and 15-30\% of individuals in the first year postpartum {[}25]. Risk factors for postpartum urinary incontinence include protracted second stage of labor, operative vaginal delivery, increased maternal parity, and larger fetal head circumference {[}4]. While physiologic factors such as intra-abdominal pressure from a gravid uterus may resolve with delivery, limited research exists regarding prevention and management of postpartum urinary incontinence.Additionally, surveys have shown that a majority of patients who report stress urinary incontinence (SUI) antepartum and 8 weeks postpartum had persistent symptoms 1 year postpartum, highlighting the symptom's high positive predictive value {[}26]. With knowledge that pregnancy is a strong risk factor for urinary incontinence and development of pregnancy urinary incontinence is strongly associated with persistent symptoms, improved management of postpartum urinary incontinence is necessary to reduce the burden it has on patients.Similar to PUR, postpartum urinary incontinence lacks standardized identification antepartum and postpartum. Studies have found that providers do not routinely screen for PFD or urinary incontinence complaints in the postpartum period {[}9]. Additionally, there is no postpartum-specific screening tool established {[}2,27,28]. Simple questions such as ``Do you experience bothersome leakage of urine?{''} may effectively screen patients and allow providers to avoid over-normalization of peripartum urinary incontinence {[}9]. This education helps prevent the patient perception that their urinary incontinence will improve spontaneously with time, an outcome which not every patient may experience {[}27].Lastly, frequent screening may also lead to improved outcomes through earlier diagnosis of urinary incontinence.In general, pregnancy-related urinary incontinence management should focus on conservative efforts including behavioral modifications and pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) with the option of including biofeedback. Behavioral modifications include maintaining appropriate bladder hygiene with limited bladder irritants and timed voids.Following education on behavioral modifications, PFMT is a first-line recommendation for management of stress and mixed urinary incontinence that remains well tolerated and effective in pregnant and postpartum patients {[}24]. A Cochrane review of 46 studies highlighted that early, structured antenatal PFMT reduced the risk of late pregnancy and postpartum urinary incontinence between 3 and 6 months postpartum in patients who were continent prior to pregnancy {[}29]. The ability for PFMT to both prevent and treat urinary incontinence may also be cost-effective; an additional meta-analysis found that antenatal PFMT continued to have risk-reduction for postnatal urinary incontinence {[}30]. This factor is important to consider while patients seek PFMT during their peripartum period, as many individuals must consider the cost of attending additional appointments antenatally. Studies have also found additional benefits of a simple antepartum PFMT regimen suggested by Woodley and Hay-Smith {[}31] as listed in Table 3, including improved sexual satisfaction, prevention anal insufficiency and also improving labor and delivery outcomes given overall increased strength and control of the pelvic floor musculature.Minimum PFMT exercise prescriptionPreviously published in Woodley and Hay-Smith {[}31].Pessaries and other vaginal inserts for SUI are additional well tolerated options for pregnant and postpartum patients. Postpartum-specific pessaries have shown improvement in urinary incontinence symptoms at both 3 and 6-month postpartum {[}32]. Specific postpartum pessaries such as the Restifem have been utilized as early as 6 weeks postpartum {[}32]. However, earlier use in a symptomatic patient could be considered for patients with minimal or no vaginal tearing from the obstetric delivery (including cesarean section) and would be at the discretion of the obstetric provider. While pharmacologic therapies such as antimuscarinics, beta-3 adrenergics and onabotulinum toxin are an option for overactive bladder, they are contraindicated if a patient is breastfeeding, limiting their clinical utility for refractory symptoms postpartum. Lastly, surgical procedures for significant, bothersome SUI are typically deferred until a patient heals completely from pregnancy, traditionally not before 6 months postpartum.In sum, maternal care providers should implement screening for urinary incontinence and offer either education on self-taught PFMT regimens or referrals to physical therapists for PFMT sessions. Future considerations may utilize telemedicine or mobile applications in order to make education regarding patient-driven PFMT available at a patient's convenience.When evaluating postpartum urinary incontinence, obstetric-related vesicovaginal fistulas (VVFs) may be considered. Although rare in developed countries, VVFs may occur in the setting of prolonged obstructed labor and often present 1-2 weeks after delivery {[}33]. Case reports also report a higher incidence of other genitourinary fistulas including vesicouterine fistulas in the setting of the increasing incidence of cesarean sections {[}34]. Thin lower uterine segments in conjunction with bladder adhesive disease and poor visualization of the vesicouterine flexure are likely the cause behind these rare fistulas {[}34]. Lastly, a handful of case reports have also highlighted genitourinary fistulas in the setting of uterine artery embolization for postpartum hemorrhage {[}35]. While all of these scenarios are rare, genitourinary fistulas must be considered if patients present with atypical symptoms such as continuous clear vaginal leakage. These typically can be clinically diagnosed with urine pooling in the vagina on a speculum examination; however, a double dye tampon test can be helpful if physical examination findings are equivocal. Additional imaging, such as a computed tomography (CT) urogram, is also important given the elevated incidence of concurrent vesicovaginal and ureterovaginal fistulas.Postpartum urinary dysfunction is a common sequalae during the immediate postpartum and fourth trimester periods. Simple modifications during recovery may reduce PUR risk. Using standardized PUR protocols allows for management in both the outpatient and inpatient settings and reduces the likelihood of bladder injury. Management of peripartum urinary incontinence necessitates early identification and utilization of conservative measures such as PFMT. Importantly, increased patient and provider education is imperative to raise awareness that bladder complaints should be standardly integrated in postpartum care.None.Purpose of reviewThe aim of this study was to describe the common postpartum urinary sequelae including urinary retention and incontinence, and to summarize the management of these conditions.Despite the high frequency of urinary disorders in obstetrics, screening and management protocols are rarely utilized by providers. Large variation exists in the literature regarding assessment of postpartum urinary retention, values of postvoid residuals and management of indwelling catheters in the immediate postpartum population. Recent expert guidance outlines a strategy for managing this condition.Research also highlights that screening for peripartum urinary incontinence is not a routine practice. The diagnosis is made more challenging by the fact that patients commonly understate and over-normalize their symptoms. Emerging studies have found that pelvic floor muscle training is cost-effective, preventive, and may improve symptoms in the postpartum setting.Increased awareness of urinary disorders in pregnancy and postpartum is imperative for appropriate diagnosis and management. Instituting standardized voiding protocols postpartum will allow providers to avoid undiagnosed postpartum urinary retention and its repercussions. Improved screening and education regarding urinary incontinence in the peripartum is important for early management, such as pelvic floor muscle training, and improved quality of life.Papers of particular interest, published within the annual period of review, have been highlighted as:While society places a large emphasis on antepartum obstetrical care, there continues to be insufficient patient education and awareness about the fourth trimester, or the first 12 weeks after giving birth, including the many short and long-term sequalae associated with delivery. Notably, education about peripartum pelvic floor disorders (PFDs) is often ignored during pregnancy, with studies finding that patients between the ages of 19 and 39 years were the least proficient regarding the topic {[}1]. PFDs are associated with decreased quality of life, psychological strain and a sense of patient embarrassment {[}2]. Out of the three domains of PFDs, urinary symptom distress is the most common in obstetrics, with 41.8\% of patients reporting these issues {[}2]. These symptoms may present at opposite ends of the spectrum during the postpartum period with urinary retention and urinary incontinence. While these outcomes may be identified during a patient's postpartum care, their physiologic consequences also predispose patients to postpartum urinary retention (PUR) and urinary dysfunction, a diagnosis that may be more nuanced to identify.PUR is a relatively common postpartum phenomenon with a wide range of incidence in the literature, ranging from 1.5 to 45\% {[}9]. This large variance is likely due to a variety of reasons, including most importantly the lack of standardized definitions and management protocols for PUR. Consequently, only approximately 30\% of United States labor and delivery institutions have an established protocol for PUR evaluation and management, which thereby contributes to a wide variation in PUR recognition clinically {[}3].There are three main subtypes of PUR, outlined in Table 1. Individuals with PUR may present with symptoms similar to nonobstetric postoperative patients, including low urine output, frequency, dysuria, suprapubic fullness or hesitancy to void {[}3]. In an obstetric-specific clinical scenario, additional findings may include displaced fundal exams (both in height and in lateral displacement) and increased vaginal bleeding due to impaired ability for the uterus to contract down {[}3]. As implied by the definition of covert PUR, individuals may also be asymptomatic. A multitude of risk factors described in Table 2 may predispose certain individuals to PUR. As such, PUR may go undiagnosed if proper screening protocols are not in place.Subtypes of postpartum urinary retentionPUR, postpartum urinary retention.Risk factors for postpartum urinary retention {[}5,6,9,10]ISC, intermittent straight catheterization; OASIS, obstetric anal sphincter injuries. Importantly, mismanaged PUR may lead to rare long-term repercussions, including noncontractile fibrosis of the detrusor muscle and bladder rupture {[}3]. Previous research has shown that PUR may take up to 42 days to resolve, with some studies also reporting prolonged voiding dysfunction at intervals 1-3 years after delivery {[}8]. These findings stress the importance of both creating and utilizing a set of standardized recommendations to manage PUR.Early diagnosis is essential in PUR management. The amount of variation in the literature regarding PUR likely leads to decreased awareness and impaired diagnosis. While the previously described definitions in Table 1 are the most common established in the literature, it is notable that there is variance in the specific postvoid residual (PVR) cut-offs {[}5,10]. The most common PVR cut-off remains 150 ml, without consequent adverse outcomes with using this volume {[}11]. Given that values above 200 ml may reflect inadequate bladder emptying and values less than 100 ml may be a normal variant, 150 ml should remain the standard abnormal PVR cut-off.The route of measurement of PVRs varies greatly in the literature. A systemic review of PUR found the majority of studies used transabdominal ultrasounds or ultrasonic measurement devices (commonly known as a bladder scanner) to measure PVR rather than intermittent self-catheterization (ISC) {[}12]. While bladder scanners may be convenient and easy to use, there is evidence these devices in the postpartum period may have low accuracy with +/- 15\% error, leading to discrepancies averaging 42.7 ml between measuring modalities {[}12,13]. Alternatively, transabdominal ultrasound is costly, time-consuming and requires a qualified ultrasonographer {[}14]. Creation of a stepwise standardized protocol including first using bladder scanners and then performing ISC if an elevated PVR is identified may therefore prevent unnecessary invasive testing.There is also significant variation of indwelling catheter usage following delivery. A review found in patients who underwent cesarean section, removal of urinary catheters greater than 24 h postoperatively decreased the risk of urinary retention, while removal less than 6 h postoperatively was associated with decreased risk of UTI and decreased the length to first ambulation {[}15]. Conversely, a randomized controlled trial found patients diagnosed with PUR had significant shorter timeframes to PUR resolution when managed with ISC, with no difference in UTI rates or length of hospital stay between the two management modalities {[}16]. A study comparing bedpan use versus mobilizing to the toilet postpartum found significantly higher micturition rates in individuals who used the toilet versus the bedpan {[}17]. This highlights simple behavioral modifications during recovery can be protective against PUR. Integration of these findings to a patient's postpartum care, with the addition of patient education on good bladder hygiene, are simple interventions that may help prevent bladder dysfunction.Utilization of a standardized protocol such as that presented in Nutaitis et al.{[}3] (Fig. 1) would therefore integrate evidence-based recommendations into a regimented postpartum bladder protocol. The protocol recommends measuring the first two spontaneous voids after delivery and/or catheter removal to ensure appropriate bladder emptying. Additionally, the protocol highlights when and how PVRs should be performed and methods of bladder rest if PUR is diagnosed. Further testing, including active void trials, is also recommended to ensure a patient's PUR has resolved. This testing can be broadly utilized in both the inpatient and outpatient setting if a patient's symptoms do not resolve while admitted. Lastly, methods of outpatient management are suggested to include both ISC and indwelling catheter after educated patient shared decision making. As the majority of PUR cases resolve within 72 h, the protocol is best integrated into postpartum care units and its algorithmic nature makes it easy to follow.Postpartum bladder management protocol.Given only 17.1\% of surveyed Obstetrics and Gynecology residents reported receiving formal PUR training, the largest area for improvement is provider education {[}18]. Formal education increased the likelihood that trainees were able to identify concerning clinical scenarios suggestive of PUR. An additional auditing study found nurses overall had minimal training on identification and management of PUR {[}19]. This study audited criteria such as encouraging regular voids intrapartum, recording strict fluid input and output both in the intrapartum and postpartum period, and ensuring individuals had two adequate spontaneous voids after delivery. After educational strategies were implemented, the study found reductions in both PUR incidence and the time to void after delivery {[}19]. Taken together, healthcare provider education on PUR is effective for properly identifying and managing abnormal voiding patterns and is important for improving patient outcomes.Active patient management remains the most important strategy for PUR management. However, bethanechol is FDA approved for the PUR treatment {[}20]. Bethanechol acts by activating bladder muscarinic receptors, which increases detrusor muscle tone to aid in bladder emptying {[}20]. However, this agent has notable cardiac, pulmonary and gastrointestinal adverse effects which limit broad application. Additionally, there is no established literature regarding the usage of bethanechol while breastfeeding; if used, infants should be monitored for cholinergic excess with symptoms such as diarrhea, lacrimation and excessive urination {[}21]. As such, nonpharmacologic management of PUR should be prioritized.Lastly, studies have also examined the use of acupuncture and the act of remedying imbalances of Qi, a concept of the vital force of life. Recent small studies involving acupuncture postpartum and auricular acupressure are protective against PUR {[}22,23].Urinary incontinence, encompassing stress, urge and mixed subtypes, is known to have a significant impact on quality of life {[}24]. It is estimated to impact 32-64\% of pregnancies and 15-30\% of individuals in the first year postpartum {[}25]. Risk factors for postpartum urinary incontinence include protracted second stage of labor, operative vaginal delivery, increased maternal parity, and larger fetal head circumference {[}4]. While physiologic factors such as intra-abdominal pressure from a gravid uterus may resolve with delivery, limited research exists regarding prevention and management of postpartum urinary incontinence.Additionally, surveys have shown that a majority of patients who report stress urinary incontinence (SUI) antepartum and 8 weeks postpartum had persistent symptoms 1 year postpartum, highlighting the symptom's high positive predictive value {[}26]. With knowledge that pregnancy is a strong risk factor for urinary incontinence and development of pregnancy urinary incontinence is strongly associated with persistent symptoms, improved management of postpartum urinary incontinence is necessary to reduce the burden it has on patients.Similar to PUR, postpartum urinary incontinence lacks standardized identification antepartum and postpartum. Studies have found that providers do not routinely screen for PFD or urinary incontinence complaints in the postpartum period {[}9]. Additionally, there is no postpartum-specific screening tool established {[}2,27,28]. Simple questions such as ``Do you experience bothersome leakage of urine?{''} may effectively screen patients and allow providers to avoid over-normalization of peripartum urinary incontinence {[}9]. This education helps prevent the patient perception that their urinary incontinence will improve spontaneously with time, an outcome which not every patient may experience {[}27].Lastly, frequent screening may also lead to improved outcomes through earlier diagnosis of urinary incontinence.In general, pregnancy-related urinary incontinence management should focus on conservative efforts including behavioral modifications and pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) with the option of including biofeedback. Behavioral modifications include maintaining appropriate bladder hygiene with limited bladder irritants and timed voids.Following education on behavioral modifications, PFMT is a first-line recommendation for management of stress and mixed urinary incontinence that remains well tolerated and effective in pregnant and postpartum patients {[}24]. A Cochrane review of 46 studies highlighted that early, structured antenatal PFMT reduced the risk of late pregnancy and postpartum urinary incontinence between 3 and 6 months postpartum in patients who were continent prior to pregnancy {[}29]. The ability for PFMT to both prevent and treat urinary incontinence may also be cost-effective; an additional meta-analysis found that antenatal PFMT continued to have risk-reduction for postnatal urinary incontinence {[}30]. This factor is important to consider while patients seek PFMT during their peripartum period, as many individuals must consider the cost of attending additional appointments antenatally. Studies have also found additional benefits of a simple antepartum PFMT regimen suggested by Woodley and Hay-Smith {[}31] as listed in Table 3, including improved sexual satisfaction, prevention anal insufficiency and also improving labor and delivery outcomes given overall increased strength and control of the pelvic floor musculature.Minimum PFMT exercise prescriptionPreviously published in Woodley and Hay-Smith {[}31].Pessaries and other vaginal inserts for SUI are additional well tolerated options for pregnant and postpartum patients. Postpartum-specific pessaries have shown improvement in urinary incontinence symptoms at both 3 and 6-month postpartum {[}32]. Specific postpartum pessaries such as the Restifem have been utilized as early as 6 weeks postpartum {[}32]. However, earlier use in a symptomatic patient could be considered for patients with minimal or no vaginal tearing from the obstetric delivery (including cesarean section) and would be at the discretion of the obstetric provider. While pharmacologic therapies such as antimuscarinics, beta-3 adrenergics and onabotulinum toxin are an option for overactive bladder, they are contraindicated if a patient is breastfeeding, limiting their clinical utility for refractory symptoms postpartum. Lastly, surgical procedures for significant, bothersome SUI are typically deferred until a patient heals completely from pregnancy, traditionally not before 6 months postpartum.In sum, maternal care providers should implement screening for urinary incontinence and offer either education on self-taught PFMT regimens or referrals to physical therapists for PFMT sessions. Future considerations may utilize telemedicine or mobile applications in order to make education regarding patient-driven PFMT available at a patient's convenience.When evaluating postpartum urinary incontinence, obstetric-related vesicovaginal fistulas (VVFs) may be considered. Although rare in developed countries, VVFs may occur in the setting of prolonged obstructed labor and often present 1-2 weeks after delivery {[}33]. Case reports also report a higher incidence of other genitourinary fistulas including vesicouterine fistulas in the setting of the increasing incidence of cesarean sections {[}34]. Thin lower uterine segments in conjunction with bladder adhesive disease and poor visualization of the vesicouterine flexure are likely the cause behind these rare fistulas {[}34]. Lastly, a handful of case reports have also highlighted genitourinary fistulas in the setting of uterine artery embolization for postpartum hemorrhage {[}35]. While all of these scenarios are rare, genitourinary fistulas must be considered if patients present with atypical symptoms such as continuous clear vaginal leakage. These typically can be clinically diagnosed with urine pooling in the vagina on a speculum examination; however, a double dye tampon test can be helpful if physical examination findings are equivocal. Additional imaging, such as a computed tomography (CT) urogram, is also important given the elevated incidence of concurrent vesicovaginal and ureterovaginal fistulas.Postpartum urinary dysfunction is a common sequalae during the immediate postpartum and fourth trimester periods. Simple modifications during recovery may reduce PUR risk. Using standardized PUR protocols allows for management in both the outpatient and inpatient settings and reduces the likelihood of bladder injury. Management of peripartum urinary incontinence necessitates early identification and utilization of conservative measures such as PFMT. Importantly, increased patient and provider education is imperative to raise awareness that bladder complaints should be standardly integrated in postpartum care.None.Purpose of reviewThe aim of this study was to describe the common postpartum urinary sequelae including urinary retention and incontinence, and to summarize the management of these conditions.Despite the high frequency of urinary disorders in obstetrics, screening and management protocols are rarely utilized by providers. Large variation exists in the literature regarding assessment of postpartum urinary retention, values of postvoid residuals and management of indwelling catheters in the immediate postpartum population. Recent expert guidance outlines a strategy for managing this condition.Research also highlights that screening for peripartum urinary incontinence is not a routine practice. The diagnosis is made more challenging by the fact that patients commonly understate and over-normalize their symptoms. Emerging studies have found that pelvic floor muscle training is cost-effective, preventive, and may improve symptoms in the postpartum setting.Increased awareness of urinary disorders in pregnancy and postpartum is imperative for appropriate diagnosis and management. Instituting standardized voiding protocols postpartum will allow providers to avoid undiagnosed postpartum urinary retention and its repercussions. Improved screening and education regarding urinary incontinence in the peripartum is important for early management, such as pelvic floor muscle training, and improved quality of life.Papers of particular interest, published within the annual period of review, have been highlighted as:While society places a large emphasis on antepartum obstetrical care, there continues to be insufficient patient education and awareness about the fourth trimester, or the first 12 weeks after giving birth, including the many short and long-term sequalae associated with delivery. Notably, education about peripartum pelvic floor disorders (PFDs) is often ignored during pregnancy, with studies finding that patients between the ages of 19 and 39 years were the least proficient regarding the topic {[}1]. PFDs are associated with decreased quality of life, psychological strain and a sense of patient embarrassment {[}2]. Out of the three domains of PFDs, urinary symptom distress is the most common in obstetrics, with 41.8\% of patients reporting these issues {[}2]. These symptoms may present at opposite ends of the spectrum during the postpartum period with urinary retention and urinary incontinence. As such, the purpose of this article is to educate providers on how to prevent, recognize and manage postpartum urinary sequelae. no caption availableGenitourinary system changes associated with pregnancy begin in the first trimester. The underlying mechanisms contributing to these dynamic changes are multifaceted. Elevation in the level of progesterone may lead to decreased urethral pressures, relaxation of urinary system smooth muscle and impaired detrusor contractility {[}3]. Renal changes include an increase in glomerular filtration rates and dilation of the ureters, resulting in increased urine production and functional bladder volumes. The enlarging gravid uterus contributes to bladder compression and can lead to urinary frequency, urgency and incontinence {[}2,4]. Together, these genitourinary system changes make bladder control issues a common phenomenon antepartum, and for some, persistent postpartum.Aspects of the birthing process are thought to predispose some individuals to the development of urinary disorders as well. Mechanical forces from pushing cause anatomical changes with inevitable bladder descent and compression. Importantly, mismanaged PUR may lead to rare long-term repercussions, including noncontractile fibrosis of the detrusor muscle and bladder rupture {[}3]. Previous research has shown that PUR may take up to 42 days to resolve, with some studies also reporting prolonged voiding dysfunction at intervals 1-3 years after delivery {[}8]. These findings stress the importance of both creating and utilizing a set of standardized recommendations to manage PUR.Early diagnosis is essential in PUR management. The amount of variation in the literature regarding PUR likely leads to decreased awareness and impaired diagnosis. While the previously described definitions in Table 1 are the most common established in the literature, it is notable that there is variance in the specific postvoid residual (PVR) cut-offs {[}5,10]. The most common PVR cut-off remains 150 ml, without consequent adverse outcomes with using this volume {[}11]. Given that values above 200 ml may reflect inadequate bladder emptying and values less than 100 ml may be a normal variant, 150 ml should remain the standard abnormal PVR cut-off.The route of measurement of PVRs varies greatly in the literature. A systemic review of PUR found the majority of studies used transabdominal ultrasounds or ultrasonic measurement devices (commonly known as a bladder scanner) to measure PVR rather than intermittent self-catheterization (ISC) {[}12]. While bladder scanners may be convenient and easy to use, there is evidence these devices in the postpartum period may have low accuracy with +/- 15\% error, leading to discrepancies averaging 42.7 ml between measuring modalities {[}12,13]. Alternatively, transabdominal ultrasound is costly, time-consuming and requires a qualified ultrasonographer {[}14]. Creation of a stepwise standardized protocol including first using bladder scanners and then performing ISC if an elevated PVR is identified may therefore prevent unnecessary invasive testing.There is also significant variation of indwelling catheter usage following delivery. A review found in patients who underwent cesarean section, removal of urinary catheters greater than 24 h postoperatively decreased the risk of urinary retention, while removal less than 6 h postoperatively was associated with decreased risk of UTI and decreased the length to first ambulation {[}15]. Conversely, a randomized controlled trial found patients diagnosed with PUR had significant shorter timeframes to PUR resolution when managed with ISC, with no difference in UTI rates or length of hospital stay between the two management modalities {[}16]. A study comparing bedpan use versus mobilizing to the toilet postpartum found significantly higher micturition rates in individuals who used the toilet versus the bedpan {[}17]. This highlights simple behavioral modifications during recovery can be protective against PUR. Integration of these findings to a patient's postpartum care, with the addition of patient education on good bladder hygiene, are simple interventions that may help prevent bladder dysfunction.Utilization of a standardized protocol such as that presented in Nutaitis et al.{[}3] (Fig. 1) would therefore integrate evidence-based recommendations into a regimented postpartum bladder protocol. The protocol recommends measuring the first two spontaneous voids after delivery and/or catheter removal to ensure appropriate bladder emptying. Additionally, the protocol highlights when and how PVRs should be performed and methods of bladder rest if PUR is diagnosed. Further testing, including active void trials, is also recommended to ensure a patient's PUR has resolved. This testing can be broadly utilized in both the inpatient and outpatient setting if a patient's symptoms do not resolve while admitted. Lastly, methods of outpatient management are suggested to include both ISC and indwelling catheter after educated patient shared decision making. As the majority of PUR cases resolve within 72 h, the protocol is best integrated into postpartum care units and its algorithmic nature makes it easy to follow.Postpartum bladder management protocol.Given only 17.1\% of surveyed Obstetrics and Gynecology residents reported receiving formal PUR training, the largest area for improvement is provider education {[}18]. Formal education increased the likelihood that trainees were able to identify concerning clinical scenarios suggestive of PUR. An additional auditing study found nurses overall had minimal training on identification and management of PUR {[}19]. This study audited criteria such as encouraging regular voids intrapartum, recording strict fluid input and output both in the intrapartum and postpartum period, and ensuring individuals had two adequate spontaneous voids after delivery. After educational strategies were implemented, the study found reductions in both PUR incidence and the time to void after delivery {[}19]. Taken together, healthcare provider education on PUR is effective for properly identifying and managing abnormal voiding patterns and is important for improving patient outcomes.Active patient management remains the most important strategy for PUR management. However, bethanechol is FDA approved for the PUR treatment {[}20]. Bethanechol acts by activating bladder muscarinic receptors, which increases detrusor muscle tone to aid in bladder emptying {[}20]. However, this agent has notable cardiac, pulmonary and gastrointestinal adverse effects which limit broad application. Additionally, there is no established literature regarding the usage of bethanechol while breastfeeding; if used, infants should be monitored for cholinergic excess with symptoms such as diarrhea, lacrimation and excessive urination {[}21]. As such, nonpharmacologic management of PUR should be prioritized.Lastly, studies have also examined the use of acupuncture and the act of remedying imbalances of Qi, a concept of the vital force of life. Recent small studies involving acupuncture postpartum and auricular acupressure are protective against PUR {[}22,23].Urinary incontinence, encompassing stress, urge and mixed subtypes, is known to have a significant impact on quality of life {[}24]. It is estimated to impact 32-64\% of pregnancies and 15-30\% of individuals in the first year postpartum {[}25]. Risk factors for postpartum urinary incontinence include protracted second stage of labor, operative vaginal delivery, increased maternal parity, and larger fetal head circumference {[}4]. While physiologic factors such as intra-abdominal pressure from a gravid uterus may resolve with delivery, limited research exists regarding prevention and management of postpartum urinary incontinence.Additionally, surveys have shown that a majority of patients who report stress urinary incontinence (SUI) antepartum and 8 weeks postpartum had persistent symptoms 1 year postpartum, highlighting the symptom's high positive predictive value {[}26]. With knowledge that pregnancy is a strong risk factor for urinary incontinence and development of pregnancy urinary incontinence is strongly associated with persistent symptoms, improved management of postpartum urinary incontinence is necessary to reduce the burden it has on patients.Similar to PUR, postpartum urinary incontinence lacks standardized identification antepartum and postpartum. Studies have found that providers do not routinely screen for PFD or urinary incontinence complaints in the postpartum period {[}9]. Additionally, there is no postpartum-specific screening tool established {[}2,27,28]. Simple questions such as ``Do you experience bothersome leakage of urine?{''} may effectively screen patients and allow providers to avoid over-normalization of peripartum urinary incontinence {[}9]. This education helps prevent the patient perception that their urinary incontinence will improve spontaneously with time, an outcome which not every patient may experience {[}27].Lastly, frequent screening may also lead to improved outcomes through earlier diagnosis of urinary incontinence.In general, pregnancy-related urinary incontinence management should focus on conservative efforts including behavioral modifications and pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) with the option of including biofeedback. Behavioral modifications include maintaining appropriate bladder hygiene with limited bladder irritants and timed voids.Following education on behavioral modifications, PFMT is a first-line recommendation for management of stress and mixed urinary incontinence that remains well tolerated and effective in pregnant and postpartum patients {[}24]. A Cochrane review of 46 studies highlighted that early, structured antenatal PFMT reduced the risk of late pregnancy and postpartum urinary incontinence between 3 and 6 months postpartum in patients who were continent prior to pregnancy {[}29]. The ability for PFMT to both prevent and treat urinary incontinence may also be cost-effective; an additional meta-analysis found that antenatal PFMT continued to have risk-reduction for postnatal urinary incontinence {[}30]. This factor is important to consider while patients seek PFMT during their peripartum period, as many individuals must consider the cost of attending additional appointments antenatally. Studies have also found additional benefits of a simple antepartum PFMT regimen suggested by Woodley and Hay-Smith {[}31] as listed in Table 3, including improved sexual satisfaction, prevention anal insufficiency and also improving labor and delivery outcomes given overall increased strength and control of the pelvic floor musculature.Minimum PFMT exercise prescriptionPreviously published in Woodley and Hay-Smith {[}31].Pessaries and other vaginal inserts for SUI are additional well tolerated options for pregnant and postpartum patients. Postpartum-specific pessaries have shown improvement in urinary incontinence symptoms at both 3 and 6-month postpartum {[}32]. Specific postpartum pessaries such as the Restifem have been utilized as early as 6 weeks postpartum {[}32]. However, earlier use in a symptomatic patient could be considered for patients with minimal or no vaginal tearing from the obstetric delivery (including cesarean section) and would be at the discretion of the obstetric provider. While pharmacologic therapies such as antimuscarinics, beta-3 adrenergics and onabotulinum toxin are an option for overactive bladder, they are contraindicated if a patient is breastfeeding, limiting their clinical utility for refractory symptoms postpartum. Lastly, surgical procedures for significant, bothersome SUI are typically deferred until a patient heals completely from pregnancy, traditionally not before 6 months postpartum.In sum, maternal care providers should implement screening for urinary incontinence and offer either education on self-taught PFMT regimens or referrals to physical therapists for PFMT sessions. Future considerations may utilize telemedicine or mobile applications in order to make education regarding patient-driven PFMT available at a patient's convenience.When evaluating postpartum urinary incontinence, obstetric-related vesicovaginal fistulas (VVFs) may be considered. Although rare in developed countries, VVFs may occur in the setting of prolonged obstructed labor and often present 1-2 weeks after delivery {[}33]. Case reports also report a higher incidence of other genitourinary fistulas including vesicouterine fistulas in the setting of the increasing incidence of cesarean sections {[}34]. Thin lower uterine segments in conjunction with bladder adhesive disease and poor visualization of the vesicouterine flexure are likely the cause behind these rare fistulas {[}34]. Lastly, a handful of case reports have also highlighted genitourinary fistulas in the setting of uterine artery embolization for postpartum hemorrhage {[}35]. While all of these scenarios are rare, genitourinary fistulas must be considered if patients present with atypical symptoms such as continuous clear vaginal leakage. These typically can be clinically diagnosed with urine pooling in the vagina on a speculum examination; however, a double dye tampon test can be helpful if physical examination findings are equivocal. Additional imaging, such as a computed tomography (CT) urogram, is also important given the elevated incidence of concurrent vesicovaginal and ureterovaginal fistulas.Postpartum urinary dysfunction is a common sequalae during the immediate postpartum and fourth trimester periods. Simple modifications during recovery may reduce PUR risk. Using standardized PUR protocols allows for management in both the outpatient and inpatient settings and reduces the likelihood of bladder injury. Management of peripartum urinary incontinence necessitates early identification and utilization of conservative measures such as PFMT. Importantly, increased patient and provider education is imperative to raise awareness that bladder complaints should be standardly integrated in postpartum care.None.Purpose of reviewThe aim of this study was to describe the common postpartum urinary sequelae including urinary retention and incontinence, and to summarize the management of these conditions.Despite the high frequency of urinary disorders in obstetrics, screening and management protocols are rarely utilized by providers. Large variation exists in the literature regarding assessment of postpartum urinary retention, values of postvoid residuals and management of indwelling catheters in the immediate postpartum population. Recent expert guidance outlines a strategy for managing this condition.Research also highlights that screening for peripartum urinary incontinence is not a routine practice. The diagnosis is made more challenging by the fact that patients commonly understate and over-normalize their symptoms. Emerging studies have found that pelvic floor muscle training is cost-effective, preventive, and may improve symptoms in the postpartum setting.Increased awareness of urinary disorders in pregnancy and postpartum is imperative for appropriate diagnosis and management. Instituting standardized voiding protocols postpartum will allow providers to avoid undiagnosed postpartum urinary retention and its repercussions. Improved screening and education regarding urinary incontinence in the peripartum is important for early management, such as pelvic floor muscle training, and improved quality of life.Papers of particular interest, published within the annual period of review, have been highlighted as:While society places a large emphasis on antepartum obstetrical care, there continues to be insufficient patient education and awareness about the fourth trimester, or the first 12 weeks after giving birth, including the many short and long-term sequalae associated with delivery. Notably, education about peripartum pelvic floor disorders (PFDs) is often ignored during pregnancy, with studies finding that patients between the ages of 19 and 39 years were the least proficient regarding the topic {[}1]. PFDs are associated with decreased quality of life, psychological strain and a sense of patient embarrassment {[}2]. Out of the three domains of PFDs, urinary symptom distress is the most common in obstetrics, with 41.8\% of patients reporting these issues {[}2]. These symptoms may present at opposite ends of the spectrum during the postpartum period with urinary retention and urinary incontinence. As such, the purpose of this article is to educate providers on how to prevent, recognize and manage postpartum urinary sequelae. no caption availableGenitourinary system changes associated with pregnancy begin in the first trimester. The underlying mechanisms contributing to these dynamic changes are multifaceted. Elevation in the level of progesterone may lead to decreased urethral pressures, relaxation of urinary system smooth muscle and impaired detrusor contractility {[}3]. Renal changes include an increase in glomerular filtration rates and dilation of the ureters, resulting in increased urine production and functional bladder volumes. The enlarging gravid uterus contributes to bladder compression and can lead to urinary frequency, urgency and incontinence {[}2,4]. Together, these genitourinary system changes make bladder control issues a common phenomenon antepartum, and for some, persistent postpartum.Aspects of the birthing process are thought to predispose some individuals to the development of urinary disorders as well. Mechanical forces from pushing cause anatomical changes with inevitable bladder descent and compression. This may result in cellular injury, causing neurogenic dysfunction and consequently diminished sensation associated with bladder filling {[}5]. Lack of bladder sensation may lead to a vicious cycle where further overdistention of the bladder may in turn result in continued damage and reduced detrusor contractility.Epidurals and other forms of neuraxial anesthesia may also predispose individuals to postpartum voiding dysfunction due to disruption of afferent bladder innervations {[}6]. This disruption consequently interferes with the ability of the pontine micturition center to signal for detrusor muscle contraction and urethral sphincter relaxation {[}7].Traumatic birth processes such as perineal edema, advanced lacerations and hematomas may cause mechanical bladder outlet obstruction {[}6]. Other sources of birth trauma may involve levator ani muscle avulsion and nerve injury involving the pelvic, hypogastric and pudendal nerves which can affect sensation and continence {[}3,8]. Obstetric anal sphincter injuries and other lacerations may also impair reflexive and voluntary relaxation of the urethrae sphincter and periurethral muscles {[}3]. While these outcomes may be identified during a patient's postpartum care, their physiologic consequences also predispose patients to postpartum urinary retention (PUR) and urinary dysfunction, a diagnosis that may be more nuanced to identify.PUR is a relatively common postpartum phenomenon with a wide range of incidence in the literature, ranging from 1.5 to 45\% {[}9]. This large variance is likely due to a variety of reasons, including most importantly the lack of standardized definitions and management protocols for PUR. Consequently, only approximately 30\% of United States labor and delivery institutions have an established protocol for PUR evaluation and management, which thereby contributes to a wide variation in PUR recognition clinically {[}3].There are three main subtypes of PUR, outlined in Table 1. Individuals with PUR may present with symptoms similar to nonobstetric postoperative patients, including low urine output, frequency, dysuria, suprapubic fullness or hesitancy to void {[}3]. In an obstetric-specific clinical scenario, additional findings may include displaced fundal exams (both in height and in lateral displacement) and increased vaginal bleeding due to impaired ability for the uterus to contract down {[}3]. As implied by the definition of covert PUR, individuals may also be asymptomatic. A multitude of risk factors described in Table 2 may predispose certain individuals to PUR.
